Title: Unfair and inaccurate
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Not a typical Spielberg movie
Review:
I couldn't feel it to be a typical Spielberg movie.Munich massacre and it's subsequent events have been shown in detail but there are some points which are left open.Movie shows psyche of people who are involved in so many killings.i felt events like this are best described in documentaries as it is difficult to fit the entire incident in a 2 hour movie.

Title: Steven Spielberg tackles a highly controversial subject with commendable tact and grace. I only hope that the same can be said of my review. Boobs! That doesn't count
Review:
Ahoy there mateys! I'm legendary seafaring movie expert Captain Remington, but that's just what my crew calls me you can call me Sir! Hop aboard my mighty vessel and I'll take you on a wondrous voyage across the ocean of cinematic entertainment! You're about to set sail on the greatest ship ever to float around in the water, the good ship HMS Supercool! Pardon me for a moment while I address the crew.

Avast me hearties! We be about do get this boat underway! If any of ye know of any reason why this ship should not be sailed, let ye speak now or forever hold ye peace! Very well! Pull my anchor! Hoist the main sailor! Man the lifeboats! Full steam ahead! Raise the undercarriage! Let's get this ship on the road! Arr! Tis a wonderful day to sail on the ocean of cinematic entertainment. The sky is blue, the waves are blue, my sailing hat is blue. Everything is blue, which is good. Can I offer you a lime? Take one for later, you can never have enough limes when you're at sea. (Sniff-sniff) There be a salty scent upon the breeze! Must be all the hot seamen on this boat! Take a break crew! Don't tire yourselves out so soon. I don't want my hot, sticky seamen to fall all over the deck. What a mess that would make! All of you have a rest. Have a lime or two.

Arrrr! I suppose ye will be wondering why I called you out here onto the high seas today. We're sea-urchin for treasure! Ha ha, a little nautical humour there! Just the thing when you're out on the movie ocean. Look yonder - there's James Cameron, he's still on the Titanic! Let it go James! Everybody knows that your boat is rubbish. Move on! There are plenty more boat fish in the entertainment sea I hear there might be an opening on the Poseidon! Har har har! Row me hearties, row! Break time's over! Three hundred and sixty degrees starport! Swab the poop deck! It's the deck that you just can't swab enough, in my opinion. Row you wretched knaves! I want to reach port before we run out of limes! Limes prevent scurvy, and the last thing I need is the health and safety people on my back. They'll hoist me from the yardarm, or worse -they'll make me walk the plank! Then some other health and safety people will make THEM walk the plank because it was unsafe for them to make me walk the plank, and so the cycle will go on.

Arrrrrr! Curse this blasted eye-patch! It be starting to itch again! It be impressive though, I'm sure ye would agree. I fashioned it myself out of a man's jock strap that I found in the skip that's outside my house. I mean outside the boat.

Now listen up me buckos! The treasure we be seeking today in this metaphorical ocean is a fishy one! Tuna fish to be exact! I reckon we've rowed out far enough now, bring in the nets boys and lets see what we find Arrrrrrrr! I thought this might happen! Sometimes when ye be fishing for a bland tuna movie in the sea of entertainment, ye occasionally find that ye have snared a dolphin-movie in your nets! The dolphin is a more intelligent breed of fish than your average tuna: dolphins can communicate with each other, they have complex social interactions and there have even been reported sightings of some dolphins wearing monocles. When ye accidentally catch a dolphin-movie ye be faced with a tricky dilemma: do ye beat the dolphin to death with an oar and throw it back overboard, or do ye take the more difficult option? Do ye crack open the movie dolphin's skull and eat its intelligent dolphin brain? Personally, I believe that it would be a shame to waste a perfectly good dolphin.

Steven Spielberg's Munich IS that movie-dolphin brain. Not a taste that everyone would enjoy perhaps, but if ye hunger for something more intelligent than this is the one for ye. Arrrrrrrrrrrr! I bet ye thought I was never going to steer this review onto the right course! Munich is great! Eat limes! www.chipremington.com - Delivering expert movie criticism to almost 6 readers a month

Title: Worked Better as a TV Movie
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: expected more from Spielberg
Review:
All the hype about Munich got to me. "Exclusive Spielberg's Secret Masterpiece, " said the front page of the December 12, 2005 Time magazine. "So sensitive it was kept under wraps, Munich is his boldest...." I had to see it and was very disappointed. It was not much different from the original 2 hour-28 minute "Sword of Gideon" with Steven Bauer, Michael York, Rod Steiger, and Colleen Dewhurst (1986). Directed by Michael Anderson (Around the World in 80 Days, Chase a Crooked Shadow, The Shoes of a Fisherman, Logan's Run, etc.)

If you've seen "Gideon..." you've seen Munich. The wonderful musical score by John Williams was enjoyable, as was the portrayal of Golda by Lynn Cohen and Avner by Eric Bana. I expected more from Spielberg and didn't get it. This is a movie I should have waited to see for "free" on TV. Two, maybe three, stars for this one.

Title: Thrilling and Deep
Review:
One of the reasons I like listening to George Carlin is because he examines big themes that encompass all of society, like war and racism, but also themes that concern individuals, right down to "people who use quotation marks in the air while they're talking." A similar thing draws me to Munich. Munich is about the conflict in Israel, but it is also about how a few men handle being assassins, and how one man handles having some of his closest friends killed. I really liked how there were a bunch of scenes where people died, but the death isn't dramatized or slowed down. It almost happens faster than you expect, which creates a good effect. Munich also does a good job of not being preachy. I think Spielberg said something like "10 people could walk into this movie and come out thinking 10 different things about what it said about the Israel conflict." Spielberg does a good job of giving a voice to a lot of the viewpoints surrounding the conflict but not hitting you over the head with any them, letting you wrestle with them. The events in the movie seemed to say "This is real. People are going to die senselessly no matter what course of action is taken," but they didn't seem to be trying to pushing you to one side of the issue. Definitely a solid movie.

A minor point: The Mosad in real life is the most advanced intelligence agency in the world. The Mosad in this movie is pretty f**king stupid.

Title: What can I say.... few movies bring tears to my eyes
Review:
A strong movie with quite a lot of questions asked but not always answered. A movie with over all strong performance by superb but not always "star" actors. Does violence breed violence?? What is wonderful about this movie is that the actors never rule the story. All actors are subdued by a story, very strong and believe it or not very non partial. I've never in my life felt 164 minutes pass with such ease. Spielberg really sticks his neck out on this one but on the other hand he raises a lot of questions that applies on 1972 as well as today. Violence always breeds violence! Doesn't it? In any way this movie in my mind clearly competes with other movies nominated this year. None of them... in my mind are as important as "Munich" a year as this...

Title: And the Oscar goes to...?
Review:
Let me start by saying that this year's Oscar nominated pictures are, contrary to the popular argument, by no means weaker than the films we heard about so much last year. In fact, the opposite seems true.

Last year's battle was truly one of the giants - between Martin Scorsese and Clint Eastwood, Johnny Depp and Leo DiCaprio, Jamie Foxx and... Jamie Foxx, Hilary Swank and Kate Winslet. All relatively, most indisputably big names, and not too many surprises at the end of the day (unless one counts MDB's eventual triumph, predicted by Ebert the night before).

That being said, we all know that the Big Five are more about the issues they raise than the people they feature, and last year the issues tackled could not have made a greater contrast with the big names behind the production. The best picture candidates studied the life of a peculiar individual, individual struggle with death, an individual's quest for identity, the life of a peculiar individual, and an individual struggle with death. Of course, one might and probably should further try to differentiate - Million Dollar Baby and Finding Neverland deal with the issue of life and death in a drastically different fashion, even as Ray and Hughes were two different and distinctive characters. Yet the sight that emerges reveals more than slight a tendency for intimate storytelling, or films that are interested in one's personal struggle rather than larger-than-life issues.

This year the direction of research and acknowledgment go the other way.

Among the Big Five, only Capote appears to look inward. Brokeback Mountain, Crash, Good Night and Good Luck, Munich all study issues critical to our day and age, i.e. life in our complex world in general. BM relates a story of two American men living a lie - a tragedy readily applicable to a number of gay people in this country, Crash studies racial stereotypes, while GN&GL masterfully reapplies a past conflict in the present situation by merely retelling a modern legend and letting the viewer's mind do the math.

Which brings us to Munich. I must say that Spielberg has been a disappointment to me lately. The man has far too much greatness and vision to be wasting his time on the likes of Minority Report, Catch Me if You Can, or War of the Worlds. There are a number of directors who could have done those and fared at least as well. To complete the picture of an utter waste of talent which Spielberg the director has been for precisely seven years now we'll say that, in spite of their occasional glimpses of greatness, The Terminal and A.I. both fared rather poorly in achieving their goals.

With Munich Spielberg repeats what he had already once accomplished with Saving Private Ryan (how that movie lost the Best Picture to an amusing, but totally inferior to it Shakespeare in Love, will forever remain a mystery), and that is an unbiased look at the events that, once having touched millions of lives, continued to change them in dramatic ways beyond repair and to the point of no return.

A brilliant study of an historical event with its consequences and ramifications, Munich wastes no time on individual actors' efforts. That is not to say that such efforts are not readily encountered courtesy of Eric Bana who wears his character every step of Avner's downward journey, or Daniel Craig who seems to be warming up for his first 007 outing, but merely that the circumstance they and other characters find themselves in is one of such magnitude that it becomes simply impossible to dedicate too much attention to these more than mildly interesting individuals.

As Saving Private Ryan once was, Munich too is chalk full of scenes of sheer and utter brilliance. A dialog between Avner and a Muslim springs to mind: one of the men yet does not know that the other is his greatest enemy and speaks freely on certain matters, meanwhile the other's face is a case study of generations that have lived through a war. There is no way I will hereby spoil Avner's eventual change reflected via, in perhaps more than one way a climactic scene, but I will say this: the pain of millions of people has never been documented out in a manner as frighteningly beautiful as that single scene.

Two things need to be said about Munich, as this motion picture begins to gather pace in the Best Picture race. Unlike Brokeback Mountain and Crash, two incredibly beautiful, thought provoking, and masterfully executed films, Munich strikes one with its lack of partiality. It does not criticize, but neither does it support any single decision that we watch its characters make. While Brokeback Mountain and Crash suggest alternatives (and Crash goes as far as implement such, too), Munich has really nothing to say with regard to its subject matter. Rather, when all is said and done, the viewer is left stunned and wondering if they agree with Avner's choice, or even if Avner himself sees it as right. This remarkable impartiality is, however, not the greatest thing about Munich.

The greatest strength of this film is its status of an eyewitness of the events far surpassing the suffering of the gay people in the present day United States, or the pain of the immigrants and people of color who often find themselves subject to life-long humiliation. The pain documented out in Munich surpasses that suffered by the above groups of individuals because the movie portrays death in such an ordinary way, and human life as worth so little a price, that the viewer cannot help but wonder if the whole affair might be one giant exaggeration.

It is not. And that is why on the night of the 2006 Academy Awards, after all is said and done, Munich will emerge with a single award - but one it deserves the most: the Best Picture.

Title: One of Spielberg's Best Movies Yet
Review:
The mixed reactions to this movie isn't surprising, there are few movies that balance action and psychological drama well. Unfortunately, what that means for movie views is that those that are attracted to the first part of the film may not understand or like the ending and vis versa. If you appreciate exploring social problems in the cinema, you will probably love this movie. If you hate following complex and at times psychologically driven plots, you may want to wait to see this film. The acting is excellent, the interweaving of stories through the main character is thoughtful and well placed, and the direction and shooting of the film, as always with Spielberg, is great.

I would very much like to see this movie pick up a few Oscars. I haven't seen many movies that I think accurately capture the internal struggles that have existed and continue to exist in the Middle East. Although, I don't think audiences should expect anything more then the focus on the specific events following the Olympics in Munich.

Title: very borderline
Review:
This was a very interesting movie, it wasn't good enough for me to watch the credits and it wasn't bad enough to walk out of. Eric Bana plays the role brilliantly as did Geoffrey Rush (thats good Aussie talent)however I thought there was a lot of unnecessary violence in it. I do realize to make such a tragedy realistic you need violence but not to this extent, all through out the movie there was bits and pieces going everywhere.

and also a lot of nudity, I mean it doesn't need to be in there, this could have been a great M rated movie...instead of a disturbing MA rating. That being said I do congratulate Spielberg on maintaining a good storyline and picking good actors. A good movie, could have been better, but there is still a chance for an Oscar

Title: Three wrongs don't make a right
Review:
The story: During the summer Olympics in Munich 1972, the Israeli delegation are attacked and killed by Palestinian terrorists, who want the world's attention for the lack of a Palestinian state. In an attempt to strike back, the Mossad (the Israeli intelligence agency) appoint a bodyguard (Eric Bana) to lead a strike-team. Their mission: To kill 11 people responsible for this and other terrorist attacks.

The verdict: While the attack is a historic fact, it's blatantly obvious Spielberg either didn't do any research or has been terribly ill informed when accepting the rest of the script. (Another possibility could be poetic license, as "inspired by real events" is stated at the beginning of the movie). Anyone reading this knowing anything about the Mossad, the world most organized and respected intelligence service, will probably laugh of the idea that they would use a couple of guys with regular jobs who've never killed before for such delicate missions.

With this in mind, the film becomes almost unwatchable and certainly way too long. There is some reasonable acting, some quality pictures, but never did I have the feeling of watching a film that justified it's huge budget. Spending just a few dollars more on a reasonable script could have made this okay. Instead, it's boring most of the time and has a couple of very funny moments (not a good sign for a movie about such a serious subject). The script proves it's awfulness once more near the end, showing Bana having memories of events he wasn't even near at the time they happened. Depending on your mood, this scene can be either appalling or hilarious.

Concluding: The Palistinians should stop killing innocent people, the Isreali should stop building a wall on ground that isn't rightfully theirs and Spielberg should stop turning turd-like scripts into movies. Three wrongs don't make a right.

Title: Disappointing...but typical Spielberg.
Review:
I keep hoping that this talented film maker will mature and resist the urge to invent new ways to portray graphic violence. Just because you can do something doesn't mean you should. There are many beautiful films out there made by little known directors who understand the fine art of allowing the actors to express human drama and emotion. Enough with the splattered brains and dangling severed limbs. Full frontal nudity on corpses...more cheap thrills. This film could have been great. He raised some interesting questions. The acting was excellent but I'm tired of being beat over the head with pointless flashbacks depicting carnage, unsuitable for people of all ages. "Munich" would benefit from about thirty minutes of editing.

Title: Good not Great
Review: Munich wants to be an important film. It uses the tragedy of the Munich Olympics to explore the effects of hatred and revenge on all involved parties especially the avengers. So I really wanted to feel moved and challenged by this cinematic dissertation on the subject much like I was with Spielberg's "Schindler's List". I wasn't. That's not to say Munich is not worth watching. It is. Just be prepared for a sophisticated version of "Death Wish" except here it's based on a true story with more depth. Perhaps that is a trivialization of a film that does engage. But I was getting weary of the main characters finding different ways to blow up their targets. I wanted more about the clash and conflict of terrorists on both sides. Spielberg attempts to be objective and he is to a point. But both sides here have their justifications of what they did and why. No doubt neither side are purely evil or completely vindicated. What drives these people to the desperation resulting in such horrific actions is really what we should be attempting to understand. Instead Munich shows us how Israel got even and why that was tough on the avengers generating more violence. I suppose the music score should include a track titled "It's hard out there for an avenger"! The acting is good across the board. Technically the film is well done. But Spileberg's direction, while competent, seems almost clinical in the depiction of this very relevant and timely subject.

Title: Worth all $10.50
Review:
Undoubtedly one of the best movies of the year. Munich delivers a value-neutral approach to the tragedy of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict, focusing not on the ethical superiority or inferiority of the parties involved but on the ultimate human tragedy of war and violence. Eric Bana delivers what I think is his best performance in years; he exhibits a skillful balance of humanity and brutality that makes his character realistic and believable.

Accusations of anti-Semitism made against the film are, in my view, unfounded. It simply portrays the perpetuity of pain and suffering caused by answering violence with violence, without answering the question of whether such a response would be justified by either side. Don't let your preconceptions about the Middle East, religion or any other issue prevent you from seeing this film. Come in with an open mind and you will leave feeling both rage and sorrow for both sides in the conflict.

Title: Brutal
Review: I don't usually write reviews on IMDb.com but after seeing this, I felt compelled to so here goes. It isn't often that I come across films like this or watch them but when I do I do enjoy it immensely. Coming from Steven Spielberg, I really expected a CGI fest or some sort of other "wow" factor. Well label me as surprised because I can honestly say that I think that this was the first Spielberg film that I would call a truly adult film: not adult as in "top of the shelf adult" (you dirty minders...you know who you are) but as an adult story. Non of the directors usual sentimentality or divulging into simplistic child like fantasy here. Based on the true story of the Black September aftermath, this film was a slow build up of tension and when it was at its peak, it threw in more tension. Yes I was bored through some of the scenes but the boredom (for me anyway) added to the tension and mood. It has been a long time since I've seen a film in which the emotions of the characters carry the film like this and I found it refreshing to see. The assassinations/murders as they happen are quick, brutal and downright shocking. Even if the viewer is clued up on the history of Black September...it still is a nail biting ride. A thinking mans film that answers some questions and leaves the viewer to ask some questions. Recommended.

Title: I didn't like this movie
Review: There was insufficient character development. The scenes depicting the Munich massacre were terribly realistic, but the terrorist when shown a few years later on was made to look like a Sunday School teacher. The five Israeli assassins did not come across as being particularly serious about their profession or even care that much about the assignment. When required to shoot their first target they fumbled so much I couldn't decide whether this was deliberate direction or misdirection. The movie had the assassins using different weapons, but apart from the obvious advantage of say, remotely detonated explosives over strangulation the movie didn't really explain why the different attack methods were deployed. The movie only hinted twice that the assassins were careful enough to clean up after themselves. Not only were they not thorough, they ran away from the scene. This would never have happened in real life. The assassins handled on site equipment without wearing gloves or even trying to destroy fingerprints. The director should know that forensic experts can find fingerprints on exploded surfaces. Also if a revolver is used, there are no spent cartridges to leave behind as clues as to what weapon was used. The movie didn't show how the informer managed to get any of his in

Title: the other side of Spielberg's paradigm
Review:
The Jews had always been recipient to numerous conflicts and atrocities since the ages of antiquity. They had been involved in slavery, territorial conflicts, racial discrimination and struggle, religious controversies and several other misunderstanding; and for that the Jews are considered to be the most sensationalized race in this world.

The most often miserable fate of the Jews has countlessly been re-portrayed in film and has captured considerable sympathizers. Since the Jews had been in conflict with different races and countries, their never-ending history of war is not anymore new to the world. And movies with their struggle against countries like Egypt, Greece, Rome and Germany have continually haunted every audience.

It's expected that if it's a Stephen Spielberg movie that it's always disturbing and moving at the same time. It's always elevated to 'Art' status and will never fail to influence the audience because of its natural feel and transcending direction and cinematography – cinema that gets through your veins and drags you into feeling the real experience.

While Spielberg had been fascinated in filming his kin's dreadful experiences in the past as the victims and losers of human abomination, Munich however gives us another perspective where the usual victims no longer play as martyrs but vengeful heroes of their own race. The story is a deviation to the usual portrayal of the Jews' martyrdom and exposes their innate nature for revenge.

Spielberg didn't reside on what just actually happened on the Munich Olympics hostage tragedy and its aftermath but he tried to depict the characters' dilemma on their given assignments since the predefined missions were not really clear and pure. Although the veil of nationalism and justice was the major pretext of their elders, Avner was caught between conspiracies he had no clue of and would somehow fail to understand unless his elders feed him the truth. The already sensationalized history of the Arab-Israeli conflict has smoothly shifted to the dilemma of the character and his allies, giving us a point of view that we need to reconsider and reflect.

It's again a masterpiece and one could just imagine how Spielberg was able to harmonize and give rhythm to a number of short scenes on the movie to create an overall theme of pure drama and portrayal of the effects of the Black September tragedy in Munich to the individuals related and to the world.

Title: Boring?
Review:
I saw the movie last night and I think it's a complete bore...Nothing to say about the tragical historical events (which speak for themselves) but if I want to see a documentary, I rather sit on my sofa and watch it... But this movie? It has no rhythm, it is excessively long, acting is too often too bad, some scenes are excessive (blood and gore, without any reason for that) and, in the end, nothing remains of a tragedy that shook the whole world. Coming to actors, although usually good, Eric Bana is simply embarrassing (it seems like he took a "sad and suffering look" from the first minute to the last...no changes were allowed). Geoffrey Rush takes his role directly from Gordon Jackson's Mr. Cowley (The Professionals) and seems to have fun with it, with the difference that Jackson is better....Lonsdale is the only one saving the bunch. Honestly, I don't see any other "real" actor in here. According to me, a very weak movie that confirms the end of Mr Spielberg's state of grace......I hope there won't be any further Indy....

Title: Misleading Movies
Review:
Firstly let me point out that I really enjoyed this film. I thought that Eric Bana and Danial Craig were fantastic! But...... sadly as with many historical films the facts become distorted by opinion. Seeing that Spielberg is of course Jewish he knowingly or unknowingly made Israel to be the victims of this terrible time. The facts being that both sides are the victims and the criminals. Directors and Producers should not try to sway public opinion with these distorted facts. I just ask that you all to watch this film with an open mind and with the knowledge that in war and terror there is blame on both sides, equally. However, as far as a cinematic experience goes, don't miss it! Danial Craig proves he is more than worthy of the James Bond casting and Eric Bana just goes from strength to strength.

Title: Pure Fantasy
Review:
I hope that people do not ascribe any accuracy to the screenplay. It is ridiculous to think that a group of assassins gather at the last moment before commencing operations and get to know one another. Furthermore, the lead was completely untrained which is probably the case since they missed many opportunities to kill their prey quickly & cleanly. The foul-up in retaining the services of a bomb maker who only knew how to dismantle bombs hardly rings true, even for the CIA!

Kushner & Spielberg bend over backwards to provide ideological balance to the warring sides. It is obvious that the true nature of professional assassins do not make for good movie material...apparently there is a need for heavy emotional conflict in order to tamper down the exactitude and clarity of purpose that is actually the makeup of the professional "agency" hit-man.

A good shoot'em up...a Western set in fashionable European locales.

Title: just...PERFECT
Review: This movie is so perfect so you think it is not true, the perfection in photographing the Araby/Palestinians in the movie was never done before to that excellence, remember Laurance of Arabia, and Omar AlMokhtat, no one in this movies reached that level of showing the arabs as real as this movie does, also the languages, see how he shows people talking in different languages, this Palestinian with his wife and daughter, talking in English (with arabic accent) to the reporter and same time talking to his wife in arabic with some french sentences, very very real, when you see a scene like that you feel you are inside the movie, and the little girl while answering the phone (the bombed phone) when she says "alo.." no one says "alo" with this accent except arabs, of course the colors used in the movie and the customs, the lighting all are so perfect, we can't ignore how Spielberg presented the case from a very neutral point of view, although he is picturing the film from the Israely point of view, but in general it was so fair in presenting the Palastenians opinion using the same sentences used by Palestinians just....PERFECT.....

Title: Good on style, highly selective on accuracy.
Review:
Did the film makers actually bother to do any research or just make this up as they went along? I suggest anyone interested in the real story behind the assassination teams dispatched around the world relating to these events dramatised in the film seek out documentaries on the subject and study the recent material now in the public domain.

I find the most risible aspect of this picture was the choice not to mention the botched assassination of a Morrocan waiter working in Scandinavia wrongly identified which brought the whole state sponsored campaign of selective targets to light and should act a warning that no matter how sophisticated your intelligence is, there is always the inevitable errors that lead to innocent casualties.

They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: In some ways it worked, in many ways it was terrible
Review:
To begin I have to say I can see in some ways why other people may have liked this movie. The movie moves along well enough, and the general storyline is engaging.

That said I have strongly felt, since "A.I.," that Spielberg is a disturbed individual. "Munich" did not change my opinion. In two cases I found what I felt to be gratuitous sexualized violence (the killing of the Dutch woman and the final "love scene"). I suspect Spielberg was going for some grittiness in those scenes, but it felt hollow and unnecessary to me. Another word that comes to mind is "exploitative."

The lack of subtleness in the Golda Meir and the "you look like your mother" part, which I found to be mind-numbing, is essentially repeated again and again throughout the movie. Wait, what? We're (Americans) suppose to identify with Avner and see our own War on Terror in the same light? No way! Could the fact that all of the Israelis speak English and the final scene with the Twin Towers in the background made that point a little more obvious?

Yeah, OK, if the initial scene's dialog had been in Hebrew with English subtitles the movie would never have done well with American audiences, I can accept that part. But given the subject matter and the analogy Spielberg is making, it would've added a lot of subtlety and reduced the opportunity for criticizing the film for having a pro-Israel bias.

Title: Surprise, surprise....
Review: Being no big fan of Mr Berg and still reeling from the very miscast and dull War of the Worlds I never the less dragged myself into Munich to see what a mess he made of what is a controversial and sensitive subject. I happened to have my 12 year old son with me (Sorry Mr Sensor) and he for all his tender years is usually spot on with his critique so I was looking forward to hearing his opinion especially as he had no recollection of the events on which this film was based. So, expecting the worst and almost hoping I was proved right in we went (Straight after 'Jarhead' in fact). Before the movie even started I new something big was about to happen, the 550 seat auditorium was full, not one empty seat that I could see. To the film. For me the very fact that there were no big names in this movie showed me The Berg was serious about this movie and that the subject matter was going to be treated both seriously and with sensitivity, could you imagine Cruise as Avner? Perish the thought. Terrorism, as we all know, is now a part of our lives and has been since the 60s and medias ability to bring it to us in full living color almost as it happens but what Mr Berg did here so very well was to both condemn it but give us an understanding of its purpose and futility at the same time. We all realize that as long as there is terrorism humanity will fight back. Direction was flawless, casting nothing less than a work of art, Cinematography outstanding and lighting nothing short of genius. OK there were a few continuity errors, so what, isn't there always and yes it was graphic at times but hey. As I said the real test for me was consulting my son at our usual post movie pizza joint. When I asked him what he thought he replied 'Can we see it again Dad? It's the best film I have ever seen'.

Title: Unfair, one-sided movie
Review:
Acting is very good. But this is unfair, one-sided movie in which they show Palestinians as bad guys and Jews are the good one, of course. Typical Spielberg's movie that shows suffer of Jews, no matter if they are wrong or right. Even when Mossad send assassins, they (assassins) suffer, because they are a goodhearted nation with honor (yeah sure). It is WRONG to kill innocent people (like in Munich), but there are many stories of killing Palestinian children by Israeli bullets shot by Israeli "soldiers". Come on, give me a break: when Israeli people kill civilians - they are soldiers, when Palestinians kill civilians - they are terrorists. I would really like to see a movie that shows suffer of Palestinians and how poor they live. Why? There are always two sides of the story!

Title: Right message with a somewhat bumpy plot.
Review:
Munich isn't the kind of movie that you walk away from feeling jolly and light-hearted. It is in many ways sickening, but I'm sure that Spielberg wanted it to have such an effect on its audience.

Munich's plot revolves around the assassinations carried out by Mossad agents against terrorists suspected of planning the 1972 Olympic kidnappings and murders of Israeli athletes. It is graphic and disturbing, but it effectively decries the violence perpetrated by both sides in the conflict.

I felt that Munich didn't do a good enough job developing characters and their relationships, but other than that, Munich was a very good movie. It's central theme was home. All any Israeli or Palestinian wants is a place to call home to share with his/her family. It also effectively showed that violence only begets more violence and that the only solution that will work in the conflict is one that does not involve revenge killings.

Title: A Masterful Theatrical Work
Review:
The summer of 1972 was a very important season for Munich. The Olympic Games had set off and the whole world was watching closely, waiting for the next world record. And so it was a huge surprise when on September 4th of that same year, a group of Palestinian terrorists, better known as Black September, kidnapped and eventually murdered eleven Israeli athletes. To add to the catastrophe, five of the kidnappers and one German officer also lost their lives. It looked as if the battle was over. However, the Israeli government felt that revenge had to be taken and in retaliation hired a group of agents from Mossad, the Israeli foreign intelligence agency, to assassinate those responsible for the attack that is now identified as the Munich Massacre.

These are the real-life events which paved the way for one of the finest movies of the year, Munich, directed by none other than Steven Spielberg, one of the most notable figures in modern-day cinematography. Munich is extraordinary in its capability to reach out to the audience and also to evoke provocative questions. Highly intricate in its organization, Munich is able to manipulate the viewer and transform any feelings of ambiguity into resentment, excitement, abhorrence and sometimes even into disgust. Disturbingly graphic, mostly visually, Munich is scarring and like the scar it leaves upon the viewer, the highly controversial questions it raises linger on, even after the movie is over (the whole 2 hr 44 min of it).

The movie stars Eric Bana, Daniel Craig, Ciaran Hinds, Mathieu Kassovitz and Hanss Zischler as the five Mossad agents (in their respective roles as Avner, Steve, Carl, Robert and Hans). Bana especially does a terrific job at portraying a haunted agent, who's often torn between the two opposing duties of work and family. The astounding Geoffrey Rush plays the role of Ephraim, the Israeli representative who must lead the Mossad to the right path (if such were the correct adjective) and Ayelet Zorer plays Daphna, Avner's emotionally-charged wife. Doubtless, the acting is terrific as the performers do a great job at thoroughly expressing their character's traits. But it's not the acting that's the winning component of the movie. Munich is the result of its highly excellent parts and as a result no one component or two sticks out(that was precisely why it didn't grab any Globes).

Munich is a masterful theatrical work and is radiant in its approach at combing politics with history. As expected, it was nominated for a number of Academy Awards as it's the type of movie that will particularly interest the academy, but no wins can be guaranteed. Although the theme of the film is highly controversial(especially since Spielberg is himself an Israeli supporter), Munich will speak out to the voters as it has to the audiences. And hopefully to all future viewers it will be recognized as the phenomenal,explosive hit it is.

Title: Nice Try, but...
Review:
First of all, I am a huge Spielberg Fan.

Thumbs way up for attaching himself to this script/subject matter in a shall we say 'European' style! Art direction: 10 out of 10. Cinematography: 10 out of 10, Music: 10 out of 10 !

My main criticism relates to the abundance of unrealistic plot holes throughout the film (especially taking into account that this is a docudrama!!! )

1) After Louis Dad revealed to Avner that they strictly DO NOT sell secret info to governments. Avner went ahead with his group 'and his bought info' without any concern. Even after running into the Arabs in Athens in the safehouse -which I understood as clearly arranged by Louis and company(no?) ...and then a week later Louis and Dad once again make a definite reiteration to the gang that they are clearly being hunted by the Arabs ...yet somehow Avner and crew need another 6 months to figure that out?????

2) Why on earth would Avner and crew put all their trust in their entire search for the 'Munich' Arabs in Louis' hands in the first place? Don't they have ANY other means?

3) the 'sensitive' peaceful demeanor portrayed by the Israeli gang was from the beginning completely unrealistic. These guys are terrorists too, ya know, HELLO!! Terrorists are violent motherf**kers, period.

---------

In addition, I felt that the last paragraph (at film's end) had the opportunity of giving the film closure. Sadly, Spielberg left us with a short blurb about how the rest of the 'Munich' Arabs were killed off, whom at his point I had almost completely forgotten about! I mean ...What about Avner ? Where did HE end up?

Perhaps in short form I would state the following: Great concept, amazing actors (Eric Bana), beautiful cinematography, beautiful music ! Somehow 3/4 along the way things get tedious and muddled . Eventually leaving us all quite confused... Help!

Title: A really good and and a mediocre movie
Review:
A really good and a miserably bad movie at the same time. Good in the way it trusts the viewer to know the historical facts; the acting is good and the photography is excellent. Yet there are so many illogical things in the screenplay it renders the whole thing mediocre. If the main point is the major character's evolving understanding that his killing of others is pointless, then too much of the film is wasted on close-ups on bombs, guns, and shootings, as they could have been kept to minimum while allocating more room to the main character's inner life and thoughts. Everything tastes half-finished, which astonishes me as Tony Kushner, whom I otherwise deeply respect for his "Angels In America" is credited for the screenplay. I really expected a less superficial work from him.

Title: Spielberg took too long to develop his message, which was unclear
Review:
I remember watching the Munich massacre on live TV. I knew that Israel had commissioned certain agents to eliminate the persons responsible. Why did it take Spielberg so long to develop this well known plot. The movie should have been cut by 1/2 an hour at least. His message was very difficult to ascertain. The only message that I perceived from this movie that there is no hope for any peace in the middle east. The killing will go on until eternity. For every person the Jews kill, the Arabs will kill a Jew. When will it ever stop? Spielberg obliterates the distinction between the Mossad, the CIA, and the KGB. According to this movie we never know whether the men assassinated were the actual perpetrators, or political killings. If that was his message, it could have been clearer.

Title: Dangerous Fiction:
Review:
I love Eric Bana and Stephen Spielberg most of the time, but this is not history. The argument has been made that, though the history may be flawed, the film should be judged on it's artistic merits. That is all well and good, but when filmmakers, especially those with the influence of a Spielberg, adjust history to fit their worldviews, people in the real world are influenced and may suffer. The fact is that a group of terrorists, who spoke in terms of martyrdom, and in the midst of a wave of global terrorism, decided to target unarmed athletes at the 1972 "Olympics of Peace."

Israel's response was reasonable and measure, if not without mistakes, undertaken by professionals to target those involve in an ongoing campaign to kill its citizens. Spielberg's naked attempt to draw some kind of moral equivalence is vile. In totalitarian states that sponsor terrorism and teach their children suicidal hatred, fanciful plays on reality such as this are of no consequence. But in democratic societies, were voters are influenced by largely fictional films pushing the phrase "inspired buy actual events," voters are moved and policies influence, which can and do put real people at risk.

I'm sure, however, that opinions like this count for nothing in the semi-reality that Spielberg lives in.

Title: Spielberg has just lost it in the end
Review:
Well what can u say Spielberg has done it again.however the one prob with Munich is it's length and he has just lost the grip from the movie in the end.When 15mins or so are remaining in the movie u feel a bit bored. That's it otherwise gr888888888 direction. good movie.i will say that every movie lover should watch it. it's a must for them. as far everyone else is concerned whom do not watch movie very often, well they should also see it.

the story is based on the tragedy that occurred during Munich Olympics 1972.the story is about what happened after the killing of 11 athletes. government elects special squad of 5 men and they go on a mission to kill 9 people whom were in this black September case.It not only tells story of that mission but also the story of the man the leader of that squad. how he feels after killing those people.it reveals the feeling of a man too.The one whom is victorious yet not satisfied.

so people u have got a movie in Ur hands see it.

Title: Spielberg's best
Review:
I think this film is better than Schindler's List, which in my opinion included a lot of extraneous footage that served no purpose other than pure sentimentality. Even at 2 hours and 44 minutes, this film doesn't seem too long.

Great performances all around, a great score, stunning cinematography.

Many people who haven't seen Munich are commenting about it. They really should see the film first. The entire Bush Administration, the Senate and Congress should see it, too.

The point is not that we should not respond to terrorism. It is simply that trying to hunt down and kill all the terrorists before they do us harm is never going to work. It hasn't worked for Israel, and it won't work for the U.S.

Title: Spielberg at his very best
Review:
I think in this movie Steven Spielberg shows what he can do with movies. I don't usually vote very high, but after I saw this movie, I think I can recommend it to anybody who likes a long during, drama/action/comedy.

The actors are showing some real talent, although they aren't really famous I think. It proves that an actor doesn't have to be famous at all, and can still be a good actor.

The very best scene in the movie I found the one with the little kid and the telephone. Although you see what's going to happen, you don't know where it ends, and also the choice of music was very good in this scene.

There was only one shot in the movie I didn't like. It is when Avner is at the Terra's of a restaurant in Rome. The camera tilts down, and after that it's going to zoom in on the table where Avner is sitting. You just can't go to zoom in a good movie. That's my opinion.

Title: It plays like a series of badly connected vignettes
Review:
Just could not find the thread that ties this movie together beyond a need for vengeance that I do not feel is even well put together.

Title: Definitely entertaining
Review:
I have just seen the new movie "Munich" and found it very interesting. However, as I watched, I recognized scenes I'd seen in another film many years before. After doing some research, I see that "Munich" is not the only film depicting these events. I think the writing in a previous film was a little better, but "Munich" is definitely worth seeing. Perhaps other films should be seen as well before judging any of them unless the viewer is only interested in entertainment. The messages of both films are difficult to determine, but they are both very entertaining. "Munich" is based on a novel and viewers would be wise to keep in mind that these films are not documentaries. Much more independent research should be done on the subject if the actual history is of interest.

Title: A great film. Spielberg and Bana at their best.
Review:
While being one the most eagerly awaited movies in recent times, there was also a real threat that "Munich" would become lost in the controversy which would surely surround it. The story deals with the Isreali response to the murder of it's Olympic athletes in Munich 1972 (i.e. to order the assassination of those considered by the Israelis to be responsible).

Spielberg deals with the story in a surprisingly unemotional manner, choosing to allow Bana to sculpt the tension in front of the camera rather than forcing it from behind. While it would have been easy to allow the story to descend into an emotional mess or an action flick, Spielberg walks the tightrope masterfully and delivers a fine movie which shall draw criticism from both sides of the conflict around which it revolves (and this in itself is perhaps it's finest commendation).

Other actors to impress are Ciarán Hinds, Geoffrey Rush and Michael Lonsdale who glide effortlessly under Spielbergs direction. The only chink in the movie comes in the form of Daniel Craig who wrestles with a South African accent throughout the movie (and ultimately looses!). Fortunately his lines are limited.

In short, a very good film.

Title: MUNICH is a mirror. You see the year 1972 with the eyes of 2006!
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Mr. Spielberg disappoints again
Review:
This movie continues the trend of mediocre or outright weak movies by Mr. Spielberg that started IMHO with "Minority Report". "Munich" has quite a few technical flaws that leave an impression that the story was too big for a director to handle. Also, there were a few instances (may be more than a few, but I'm not a historian) when actual facts have been manipulated to fit the story. This is particularly wrong when author positions himself as an "independent" and "not taking sides". The acting was very good though, Bana has done a brilliant work. Unfortunately, bright acting with poor directing doesn't leave much better impression than bad acting itself. All in all, in recent years Mr. Spielberg has been far more successful producing rather than directing.
1 out of 3 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: OK. Not great
Review:
I guess I expected more from Spielberg. I thought it was slow toward the end and made the Israeli's look a little bad. The story is a tragedy and reminded me of the chaos that existed at that time. I had forgotten about Black September and the assassinations and tragedies that occurred. While I hope that everyone remembers the massacre at the Olympics but it doesn't seem we have learned from this lesson. I think that the film suffered from a bit of poor editing and could have been cut from the 2+ hours that it runs. I was totally confused by the ending and really wonder whether or not the Israelis achieved their objectives in the end. Worth watching on DVD.

Title: This is a great movie about the emotions involved in the aftermath of the attacks, but lacks historical facts
Review: This movie is done in the vein of the countless other historical epics that Spielberg has directed, and will move anyone who sees it. While it is based on true life events, it appears as though it is mainly directed toward connecting the events in the film to our modern day struggle with terrorism, rather than simply stating the facts. Largely unknown to most of the "Munich" audience, another movie was made for TV based on the same novel by George Jonas almost exactly twenty years ago called, "The Sword of Gideon." I watched this movie about two years ago, and while it doesn't convey as much emotion as "Munich" (i.e. lower budget and non-inventive camera work), it does cover a larger time-line with many more facts. There tends to be definite political statement made in "Munich", and therefore I would recommend seeing both movies to get the big picture. If at all possible, watch the "Sword of Gideon" first to get a more historical background, and then watch "Munich". If you just watched "Munich", and are wondering what happened to Avner beyond where the movie leaves off, watch "Sword of Gideon".

Title: a fast paced suspense thriller grounded in real world events
Review:
if you are not a student of history, you might view this film as just another thriller; but if you know anything about the events of munich in 1972, you will be driven to look for a deeper meaning in each twist and turn of the road.

why were the israeli atheletes slaughtered? is israel's relentless quest for retaliation justice or revenge? you might come into the film pondering these questions but soon you will be drawn to the action and the conscience of one man: avner. he is played to perfection by eric bana. strong yet sensitive, focused yet torn by doubts, he is the perfect hero for this film.

the rest of the cast and the settings are superb. only one criticism: trim about 15 minutes off the running time and this film would rate a 10.
0 out of 1 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Excellent Lesson on the Importance of a Homeland
Review:
There is a lot to like in this movie. Excellence all around. Acting, directing, writing, cinematography, pace, editing, message(s) were all at that level. One step below greatness, but still very, very good. These days you can do a lot worse when buying a theater ticket. Get a little history lesson too. I was 23 and just starting law school when Munich happened, and as a past athlete, the events were seared into my head. This movie has given me a more complete understanding of what was at stake...so far away. Both sides are shown to be doing what they do in search of a "real" homeland for their peoples. This, in turn, requires themselves to suspend their adherence of the ethical rigors of their respective religions, so that they may carry out those actions, albeit heinous, that they feel are necessary.

Title: Superb...
Review:
Should be a two disk set with Schindler's List...

No one is discussing the fact that this book was filmed before, for HBO in 86, as "Sword of Gideon"...

Same characters (more or less)...

Steven Bauer was especially good as Avner That was excellent, but this has much more depth...

The ending should strike home with a lot of people...

One of Spielberg's best...

Eric Bana is outstanding as is the rest of the cast...

Locals: A Editing: A Acting: A Length: Long but worth it...

Good to see a serious film that makes you THINK!

Title: Munich
Review:
this is a bold movie to make and Steven makes abunch of bold movies like Saving Private Ryan and Schindlers List but this might be one of the boldest movies of them all. Steven Spielberg i won the most entertaining directors of them all, but when I saw the movie I just though it wasn't that entertaining , the movie was to long for me be it has good directing good script and okay acting but I thought and everyone thought it was going blow everyone away, but weather you hate the movie or like it this movie has Oscar written all over this movie. This movie will not be ignored by the Oscars at all because the Oscars like these kind of movies, but this movie will probably be in 3-4 nominations at the Oscars it has a good screenplay Steven Spielberg might even get his 3rd Oscar for best director Eric Bana is not Oscar material in this movie but soon I think he will get an Oscar, the score is very pervasively and will maybe an Oscar so this was my summary I hope you liked it if you have any comments you want to say to me my email is robertbenfer@yahoo.com

Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. Title: Acting was impeccable, dialogue good if somewhat predictable
Review:
Seeing Munich last Saturday, I came away emotionally exhausted, my husband left feeling unresolved. I found some of Spielberg's attempts at humor distracting, such as the accountant making abundantly clear he wanted receipts!!! The tenor of the film seemed a little uneven, perhaps that was the intent, the whole situation was pretty untenable. Not sure what to make of Papa and/or Louis, who proclaim such disdain for what governments can and do do, but make a very comfortable living off of that ambiguity. Not clear why such relatively untrained people were brought in for these jobs. Amazing what they pulled off, all things considered. Are targets really that easily accessed? Eric Bana has been a personal favorite since Blackhawk Down, I thought he did the best he could with Hulk, he was very effective in Troy, or was that just by way of contrast with Bloom and Pitt? Still remember "Papa" from "The Jackel"(the original one:), he continues to be convincing and effective. I thought perhaps Louis had the most difficult role of any, lacking the passions of his father, how did he feel about his "job." Clearly I need to view this film again. No doubt all my questions are answered. In the meantime, though, I applaud the film and Spielberg. It is the first feature-length film to take on this horrific time and crime. I remember the made-for-TV movie, of many moons ago, with Lindsey Wagner as a compassionate flight attendant who talks to one of the terrorists, I almost feel like that depiction was more evenhanded, perhaps. Of course, it stops with this event's playing-out.

It seems clear to me Ms. Meir's motivation was pretty purely revenge/vengeance, not sure she had any good alternative choice, though.

Those are my thoughts, as of this day!

Title: Great film
Review:
This is a very significant film. It hammered me hard, both with its action and with its powerful message. This is a dead serious movie. It is a mistake to think of it as a documentary or history. Fiction is better suited to portray the moral morass of terrorism better than any history. The protagonist's final resolution exposes the heart of terrorist darkness: whether carried out by Palestinian fanatics or the state of Israel,the entire cycle of terrorism is dehumanizing, savage and--in the end--futile.

My only criticism is that the plot lagged occasionally, but this is a minor flaw. The biggest problems I have seen are the many reviewers who believe they have identified a pro-Israeli or a pro-Palestinian bias. These kind of reviewers need to get a life: Munich is a balanced pro-humanity work of art. Forget Arabs and Israelis: this movie could just as readily be portrayed through Croats and Serbs, Serbs and Kosovars, Turks and Armenians, Hutus and Tutsis--anywhere the cycle of terrorism, ethnic rage and revenge has shredded the bonds of humanity.

Title: Outline of long - ago terror
Review:
I was astonished when I saw the first previews of Munich late last year. And I was amazed that Spielberg showed the guts to get his hands on quite a difficult plot while other directors unleash big monkeys on major cities.

However I was afraid that, despite the fact that Spielberg directed it, the movie might be a bit, too American, too Hollywoodish, too action-crammed to be informative.

But recalling Spielbergs work in Schindler's List and trying hard not to recall War of the Worlds, I found a way to the cinema. Well it does have one thing with unleashed monkeys in common: don't buy a big soda. The movie will last until the end of time.

Which is on the other hand not bad, because it passes time quite well, without being exactly entertaining. Which it of course, should not be. You cannot expect to see a work-over of a terrorist assault and walk out with a big smile on your face. It's not going to happen. So the movie does what I was hoping it would do. Display a story that makes you think, makes you wonder about terrorism, wonder about it in a serious, unarmed way.

Well sounds too good to be true if you are out to see a movie like Schindler's list, and I dare to also mention 8 mm here. And yes it is. Spielberg got the script of a children's play book, or mickey mouse, or I do not know what. Except for the perfect display of the location (even the street names are right), there is no truth in it. Surely the overall ending is still true, but the way things happen is just imagined.

That does not make it a bad movie though, as the bottom line is still kept.

Title: Not so great
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.
