Title: Best Movie of the Year
Review:
In a year of really good movies, I believe MUNICH was the best of them all. It's a big movie that because it struck me on so many levels, felt very personal. While I realize that some people like to minimize Spielberg's work at times, this movie proves yet again that there is no filmmaker who can make a movie hum like he can. MUNICH is really a thrilling ride but it is not fun at all. It's exciting but it's painful. It's long and it feels like it never ends but (unlike A.I.) that was okay because it just works so well. In fact, I believe that this was Spielberg's message -- this movie is going to keep going and going, just like the cycle of violence that is represented. To make such a statement resonate, and do it in a way that sucks you into the story and the movie as an entertainment, shows just how ambitious and successful this film is.
0 out of 1 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Story chewed up by too much action
Review:
"Munich" tries to cram too many shots and explosions per minute, leaving the characters behind. On the other hand Spielberg was obviously trying to carry a message, but the movie came out is too shallow to really immerse you and make you feel what he is trying to tell. There are a few key dialogs, but they sound a bit artificial -- maybe they could sound better, but not in this movie. Eric Bana also does not seem to keep up with the leading role, which in a way may be intended -- it is unclear if Avner is in control of the events or vice versa, but still his acting could be better. Overall, the movie is substantially worse than I expected.

A suggestion: see "Sword of Gideon" (1986) if you can find it, doesn't matter before or after "Munich". IMHO it develops better portraits of key characters, and generally gives the story a much better texture. It concentrates on people and ideas rather than the events, and that's what this story is all about. The messages in these two films differ somewhat, and you may agree or disagree with either or both, but either way "Sword" is absolutely worth seeing if you are interested in the subject. I would also suggest watching the documentary "One Day in September" (1999) before watching the movie(s), for more detailed background.

Also, don't take user ratings too seriously for these particular moves, because as someone else correctly noted here, many people pay more attention to political aspects than cinematographic.

Title: Good,Good
Review:
Munich is a great film.In two hours and thirty minutes,you have a state of thrilling constant.It is not bored in any moment. Interpretations are correct.The final is the part of movie that i didn't like very much. In the technical capitol, photography and mounting are brilliant. Although, i don't have lived in those years, i think that the movie is set very well in that period.Spielberg has worked how he's in the habit. Munich is better than Saving Private Ryan's,however this isn't than spectacular. Munich will join in the selected group of mythical movies and normally, must be a favorite movie in the all international movie trophies of this year(Oscar,Golden Globe,Venecia,Cannes,Valladolid,Sitges,San Sebastian and more).

completely recommendable.

Permalink

Title: True Art
Review:
I don't remember another movie entering into my dream life. Munich did. Seamlessly constructed, one follows image upon image as in a dream and its substance seeps into your soul. The plot is carried so you do not have to use your mind to sort out the sequences. You can lay back to receive the story...the Dream. You are given enough time to digest the powerful images but none are cheapened -- sustained beyond dream time -- as artifice -- either to manipulate emotion or ideology. Each character rings true. You meet the assassins from your heart. The ruse of the word "terrorist" is made manifest. What empowers certain people to legitimize their violence and eschew the label, "terrorist"? You understand that it IS a tough world out there, baby. That is starkly made manifest. This is not a film to be entertained by but to be enlightened by; enlightened, not in the sense of weight, for it is heavy...but in the sense of widening insight into the nature of Reality; to see its truth to help you walk your walk with a clearer vision. I honor Spielberg and Kushner Bana for their gift, their artistry. Thank you.
0 out of 0 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.

Title: astonishing
Review:
Why astonishing? Because it learns to think, what is bad, and that is good, because it gives a choice, to see things in another perspective, because it's not just one sentimental drama, it has no happy end, it's has no end at all. We self have to decide then it;s will stop. It's us, who has to make end to it. It's not sympathize to one or other side, it just gives a lot of time to think where all that go? Where the world goes? And who has right to stop or continue all that madness? Not recommended for short-minded people with just one point of view. Because then you just will see black or white, and that's not what Spielberg wanted. I think this is masterpiece, and the most important, such a masterpiece that lets us to think. Where all this world going too?

Title: Spielberg has done it again.
Review:
Spielberg has done it again. This film, combined with the tremendous acting power of Eric Bana and the up and coming Daniel Craig among others really comes together to create this epic masterpiece, some might complain about its length, but I have to be honest, the shorter the film (a good quality film) the worse, I love to watch the same characters over a length of time and watch them evolve and become a different character than the one they were at the start of the film. Visually this film is on par with nothing, as it exceeds every boundary while keeping true to the gritty realism that permeates throughout it. I look forward to more work from Spielberg since he seems to only get better with age.

Title: i thought it was poor
Review:
Despite all the glowing comments I thought it was a poor movie...wet streets in London, Athens, Paris Rome etc, for me it was pure Jewish propaganda which we have come to expect from Spielberg when he makes a film about the Palestinians and there issues I may take note.

For me it was like a poor Freddie Forsythe, I felt that the whole movie was about Vengeance...no trial...no Jury...no Judge, a lot of the acting was hammy and contrived, and whilst it may be based on a true story...which I remember.......... was it really???

Spielberg best years are behind him in my opinion, without wishing to sound anti-semitic I can only assume it's Oscar nominatinos were due to the preponderence of Jewish supporters in the Academy

Title: Avoid. This is not - I repeat NOT a must see at all!
Review:
Spielberg should not get away with this mindless violence. There is virtually no character development at all. The plot in it's entirety is known within the first 5 minutes of the film. Consequently you can easily leave your seat 3 or 4 times to get popcorn, drink or use the facilities and return having missed nothing at all. For all who loved the flying limbs of Private Ryan, there is more here for your delight. Yes we do have imaginations and we did not come to see FX. Good news is this is my last Spielberg!The movie could have used some romance to take away briefly at least from the bullets and bombs. This simply made the film even more unbearable and hastened the onset of bordem.

Title: Overly didactic
Review:
Of the five best picture nominees for the 2006 Oscars, three are overly didactic (the other two being "Good Night and Good Luck" and "crash." However, this one takes the cake. There is waaaaay too much debate and discussion. What is more, the actual participants have stated publicly that they were NOT so ambiguous. Finally, this movie is too long by at least 20 minutes if not 45. Whole sub-plots could be eliminated and it would make no difference.

I think this movie is the cinematic equivalent of overcooked spinach - people see it because it seems like it will be good for them, but in fact its overdone to the point where it looses its value.

Title: Good Pro-Israel Propaganda Film Steve-O
Review:
This movie is basically a melodramatic propaganda film. According to the film Israel's desire for a homeland is a noble aspiration and killing off Arabs or other innocent bystanders might be difficult for our sentimental tough guy assassin with a conscience but its worth it for 'a home.' Apparently if you are Palestinian you can go live anywhere else in the world and you will be warmly embraced. You will be given cookies, a warm blanket, and new shoes. Stevo-O made some half-hearted attempts to humanize the Palestinians in the movie but ultimately his agenda was impossible to ignore. Steve-O go make ET 2 or something and spare us.

Title: Incredible ride through Europe
Review:
This had an excellent Bourne Identity feel about it -- something I did not expect to encounter.

The reviewers acted like this was a movie about Eric Bana's mental state, but it is in fact a very convincing account of how the Mossad probably functioned after Munich.

This was undoubtedly the best performance of Bana's brief career, and the movie's minor flaws are covered up by an incredible supporting cast.

The film borders on three hours in length, and the film features one tense moment for each of the 160 minutes.

Title: I expected the worst, and got it.
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: I don't want to see it again but I think it's a masterpiece
Review: I would like to disagree with comments that I've just read from pfarmer891 about Spielbergs Munich. I think that the main message was totally overlooked and your comments were mostly concentrated on facts that sometimes are useless. So what if the Fiction movie is not totally based on facts, but do you think you can actually get those facts straight in a conflict like this. If the movie ads on in order to created a clearer message, I believe it's not a crime. And I don't think that the message was the standard Hollywood "why can't we be friends". I thought it was the message of desperation and hopelessness about the situation in Middle East. And it makes the story even stronger when we look at out the same conflict in 2006 and realize that nothing has changed, because the violence has continued. If Spielberg would have taken sides, then that would've been a standard for the modern Hollywood - Israel is the victim and Muslims are all terrorists. I thought it was a very brave move by Spielberg to try to analyze the conflict from words of both Israelis and Palestinians. The "safe house" part of the movie might have seem ridiculous to you, but why, is it impossible now for people of those to nations to sleep under one roof? If you believe that, then the conflict is inevitable in your world. I think people who go to see this movie, should not come there trying to dissect every setting and decide if it can be fact or not, but look more deeply into the meaning of the film. Try to get rid of all the previous conceptions and just watch it from both sides and then see if you can decide who is right. I think that's the point, that it's no one. Too many people have died to naively believe that any of the allegations of the truth, be it from Israelians or Palestinians, can be justified.

Title: An intelligent thriller with an important ethical question, but sometimes to kitschy
Review:
Not to lose to much words, quote Rathko: "'Munich' is an intelligent and gripping thriller" and offers the ethical bias and conflict that lies in the question: is it right to fight enemies, which use all bloody possible ways and methods of achieving there goals, yourself with all possible (even illegal) methods? To be judge, jury and executioner? Is this right or do I become even myself then a terrorist? And where then lies the difference between them and me? Positive: The movie asks this question and can't it. Negative: The display of the inner doubts and bias is too clichéd and superficial to be plausible and the the persistent references of the Munich-Massacrer in the form of dreams of the main protagonists are just too kitschy and overblown to be a real outstanding film.
0 out of 0 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Talky - Give us Credit, Steven
Review:
This film takes on a serious issue and one that Spielberg is obviously passionate about. At its weakest, it's preachy and excessively talky, not simply giving us something to think about -- the entire film does that -- but instead pushing us in particular ways and assuming we won't get it. At its best, it lets us, the audience, do the important work, such as weighing the morality of revenge when it seems to be costing much, much more than the bargained for price, or drawing lines, such as when is it "terrorism" and when is it "making a point"? The performances are quite good (it was fun seeing "Hector" and "Gaius Julius Caesar" working on the same team!).

Title: great movie that will open your eyes
Review:
Munich is a great film that shows incredible depth into the Israeli-Arab conflict that dominates world news these days. The mostly unknown incident at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Germany,was unfortunate, but the film enlightens us with the prejudice that feeds the fire of the war today. The film is completely objective, though viewed through the life of one of the Israeli assassins. When I first heard of the movie, I thought "oh great, another biased film for the public to misunderstand", but I was completely debased. Arabs and Israelis are both represented as great people, loving and caring as we consider ourselves, but unfortunately consumed by a never ending war. I was very impressed with Steven Spielberg, but am disgusted that the film isn't getting the attention it deserves.

Title: too long and too contrived
Review:
Grindingly long revenge film in which the instrument of revenge begins to have moral qualms half way through. I doubt Isrealis would choose someone who doesn't have clarity on what his job is and who would have any problems carrying it out. Also, rather simplistic, but at the same time, muddled view of the conflict in the middle east. Also, the action at times seems more like a phony action movie rather than a realistic portrayal of events. Seem to be a few rather miraculous escapes. The mysterious information supplier who avner an amateur at this type of work, finds rather easily is never explained. All of Spielberg's message movies (Color Purple, Schindler, Amistad, and now Munich) have something missing.
1 out of 7 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: It's Spielberg - so it's Amazing!
Review:
I went in expecting what I walked out with. This was beautifully acted, wonderfully shot. The long movie held the audience and there was not one sound all through. It was like Schindler's List. A hushed reverence. Eric Bana is marvelous in a very difficult role. The lesser known actors were wonderful - including Daniel Craig who will soon be very well known as James Bond. This movie showed his acting skill rather than as a sexy secret agent as 007 is sure to do. No matter the controversy of "showing the other side" - the real heroes are the avengers, it just humanizes them instead showing them as robotic killing machines. The Black September group and the Palestinians are portrayed as they were/are. The Israelies are always obsessed with revenge because they must show the world they cannot be crushed. An eye for an eye - . Spielberg continues to remind the world "Never Again". I laud him for this. We urge him to continue making movies in this vein.

Title: Good Movie
Review:
I wouldn't rate this with Apocalypse Now, Full Metal Jacket, Saving Private Ryan, or some other Combat/War based films I feel are classics, but it's a solid movie.

The casting was excellent, I thought Eric Bana did a convincing job in his role. He basically gets across the point that he's a man torn between devotion to his country, his family, and his sanity. I enjoy films that focus the strain put on the mind of the warrior (or in this case assassin) much more than films that just glorify the actions of the "hero". The mental affects that a mission of this type, one that's so up close and personal to those targeted, they clearly should be a focal point of his character and I felt the film did a nice job of showing that stress.

The effects were nicely done and I felt that Spielberg did a good job of making sure the props and environment appeared early 70's ish. I also didn't feel a sense of political propaganda either; the Palestinians were doing what they felt was right and the Israelis were responding in a way that they felt was right. I felt that in this case a story was told rather than a justification for one side or the other.

It was definitely a solid film, in this case I only rented it but had I saw it at the theater, I would have left satisfied.

Title: Is this a remake of the Sword of Giden from 1986?
Review:
I am astounded at how similar this movie is to an earlier title called the Sword of Gideon directed by Michael Anderson. Most of the scenes were identical and even many of the lines were the same. Almost all of the characters were the same names. Both were excellent movies, however I am a bit disappointed that Spielberg has not done something more original. Perhaps there is some story behind these two films that is not so obvious. Having said that, the story is excellent, the message is compelling and I would definitely recommend seeing it. I wish that Spielberg would have gone into more detail of how the Germans handled (or mishandled) the situation.

Title: Wow
Review:
This movie is beyond remarkable. What it must have been to the men who lived it, and their families. I was only eleven years old at the time of the Munich Games, but I do remember the news broadcasts during that time. I applaud Spielberg for bringing the incident to younger generations, and filling in the memories of the rest of us. Even though the movie runs 2 hours and 44 minutes, it doesn't seem like it at all. There is so much action and keeps you pinned on every word from the opening credits until the end. Bano's performance was beautiful! And despite the very serious nature of the subject, several lines scattered throughout the movie brought giggles from the audience. Bravo!

Title: Excellent but no masterpiece
Review: "Munich" is an very good movie but not Spielberg's best. I was alive at the time of the 1972 Olympics and watched the whole drama unfold on T.V. For many Americans, it was the first time we'd ever seen the ugly face of terrorism. This movie is that always dangerous combination, a docudrama, a film 'based upon real events.' In using George Jonas' 1984 book "Vengeance," Spielberg makes a critical error, for the book was widely criticized as inaccurate by knowledgeable sources, including former Mossad chief Zvi Zamir. The film is up to the usual high standard of Spielberg's past work - the film is intensely interesting and has excellent production values. However, it succumbs to some idiotic B-movie staples of past Holly wood fare, such as have two opposing groups - one Israeli and one Palestinian - share the same safe house, in which they meet with guns drawn but later become pals and house mates. Ridiculous. I enjoyed the movie but Spielberg takes a surprisingly soft view on terrorism, considering that he is a Jew. The PLO and the Mossad agents come across as morally equivalent, a view I do not share. Spielberg descends - for at least part of the movie - into standard Hollywood "Why can't we all be friends" bathos. Pretty simplistic and not very good history either. This movie is a fine example of why it is dangerous to rely upon Hollywood and movies for an accurate view of history. "Munich" is fictional, but uninformed viewers may take it as fact, which is a disservice to those who died. If you want a better view of terrorism, rent "The Battle of Algiers," a fictional movie but one universally praised for its accuracy. In fact, so accurate is "Battle" that would-be terrorists and also counter-terrorists screen the film. Of course, Spielberg's film is the better entertainment of the two, so pick on that basis. I give the film an 80 out of 100, or a 'B' grade. Nice effort but flawed. I wish he'd been willing to take a stronger stand morally. Whatever acts have been committed by both sides since then, Israelis were the victims at Munich, not the PLO.

Title: Spielber plays big to the Hate Israel Crowd! Oscar Time!
Review:
Spielberg has won the acceptance of the Hollywood community at the Oscars (and the nominations) because he has made the film they all wanted made.

His argument that the Israelies are somehow "just as bad" as savages who killed their athletes is right where the community wants to be.

Leni Riefenstahl and Michael Moore did their best to spew nonsense on behalf of their causes, but were hampered slightly because people knew they were making documentaries, and so they looked at their work a bit critically. Even if they didn't expect the "documentries" to be composed of falsehoods.

Spielberg's brilliance was in creating a new hybrid "Historical Fiction" category, thus putting his audience to sleep, thinking they were watching actual true events.

This was smart because: He could therefore focus on the murderers as victims, humanizing them. (Not bothering to show the murdered athletes until the movie was over).

He could create a fictional "self-doubt" imposed on the Israeli hit men, where none actually existed.

Look for him to clean up at the Oscars as the self hating Jewish community rallies around this commercial failure of epic proportions.

Title: Theoretical portrayal of events to avenge murder of Israeli athletes at Munich.
Review:
I saw this film in Boston, Massachusetts last week, but not from choice, rather doing a favor to a friend who did not want to go alone. It does have you holding your breath in places, and in other places closing your eyes.At least I closed mine occasionally, as too much explicitly detailed violence and sexual scenes distresses and irritates me. True the direction of the story was well done, as Spielberg usually does. The casting was excellent, and there were good performances put in by the entire cast.

The only positive for me about this film was the portrayal of the effect on the character(s) of the job they were doing. Would that tinseltown would learn the lesson and stop dishing it up.

Title: Spielberg tries something new
Review:
In his political movies, Spielberg tends to polarize good from evil excessively to a point where some of the realism of characters and their feelings are lost.

Munich was a welcomed change. With all character glorification/dehumanization aside, Spielberg now takes us to a frame of time in 1972 which I haven't experienced since.. 1972.. The remarkable recreation throws you right into action and the emotional depth and inner moral conflicts that awashes these characters with genuine feelings that touch you and conflict you.

Most moviegoers will feel detached from the political message of the movie but it shouldn't discourage anyone to enjoy this true Spielberg thriller. Nudity and Violence abound... although in awkward ways.

Title: Spielberg's finest hour? Perhaps his most subtle
Review:
Works as a thriller and as astute social commentary, teaching an example of a very under-appreciated irony: extreme nationalism kills trust between compatriots. Spielberg even ties in contemporary international terrorism of the film's day in a way that makes sense and asks serious questions without over sentimentalising, picking sides, or slipping into bathos. But none of this stops the film from being exciting and jaw-dropping as a thriller, as well as a sure fire catalyst for Daniel Craig's next assignment debuting as Bond in the following year. Just don't expect a happy ending.

Title: Bad Message
Review:
I found the new Spielberg movie to be very well done, as would be expected. However, I found the message in the movie appalling and disheartening. To try and equate the wrong doing on those two sides is ludicrous. The Palestinians make it part of their interest to kill the innocent, while the Israelis had unfortunate victims in what can only be considered a mission for the future protection of other Israelis. I would be lying if I said that this movie did not have an expected view point but nevertheless I found it to be odd. We have no problem demonizing the Nazis for killing millions, but we fail to see that the radical muslims would do the same if they had the means to. Somehow we want to find the good in them, like some sort of pet project.Spielberg has really sold his soul on this one. But what do you expect from Hollywood?

Title: Monumental
Review:
Very simply, truth is stranger than fiction. I feel this picture was superlative, it was real, and that's the way it was.

Three cheers for the Israelie's. Never Again!!!!!!!!!

I do not what more to say, the story was real, the acting superb,all the characters depicted where excellent.

I would certainly go to see the picture again. It was wearing but it was worth it. I have never clearly understood what happened in Munich the portrayal was entirely visible.

I went with my wife and it was tough but, real movie for her absorb. My son a daughter will be my next guest to see it.

Stephen Spielberg AND COMPANY. did a wonderful piece of work, and should be given many accolades for it.

Many thanks, I think I have covered all base and it was just great.

Title: this film is biased, but not in ways many will find
Review:
contrary to some posts here, this film is biased, but whether that is a fault of its production or a biased opinion of its producers is hard to tell.

my reasons for this are simple, if you sit down and thoroughly read through the facts of the Munich siege you notice a lot of things missing from the film, and some of it is shown in a light that makes the terrorists (and sometimes the Palestinians as a whole) look like they were cold blooded animals, what is depicted in the film is for bits of the actual story, known to be not true.

also, the film is based on the book Vengeance which the author of the said book claims to be the team leader, but many people with first hand accounts of all that happened during and after Munich dispute his claims to this.

other than that the film is OK, though some bits are horrific and are not for the easily distressed, towards the end of the film though it does tend to drag and the ending was a little pointless.

this isn't a film i'll be in a hurry to watch again and I wont be buying it on DVD, I feel Spielberg has regained some of his credibility in this film after the abysmal War of the Worlds, but he still has a lot to go

Title: updated remake
Review:
Over the years, I have really enjoyed Steven Spielberg movies, but this one I can only give 3 stars. Most people will find this a really great film, however, for those of us who remember the original TV movie "Sword of Gideon" (1986, starring Steven Bauer["Scarface"], Michael York, Rod Steiger, and John Hirsch) you will be extremely disappointed. "Munich" follows "...Gideon" almost scene by scene. They are the same movie 85% through; absolutely no originality. This seems to be a growing trend i.e. "Brothers" and "The Sons of Katie Elder" etc.

In summation, save your money and rent "...Gideon". The only REAL difference is the amount of fake blood.

Title: very precise

Title: Spielberg breaks new ground
Review:
This film has stirred up a wide variety of reactions, from the typical unjustified criticism provided by people who won't even see the film to the fluffier question of whether or not Steven Spielberg regains his status as film's top director from Peter Jackson. All of those miss the point. What Munich REALLY accomplishes is the deglorification of violence in entertainment through its story of a vengeance squad put together to hunt down and kill those involved in the murder of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olymkpics. And he doesn't do it by force-feeding the audience, just with Hitchcockian style behind the camera, a questioning script and an unassuming -- but brilliant -- cast led by Eric Bana.

Title: Munich: Spielberg's best film in years
Review:
In my opinion, Munich is Steven Spielberg's best film since Saving Private Ryan. From the opening scene with a depiction of the Munich massacre to the very end in New York, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. It was one of the few times that I could feel my pulse racing during a movie. Spielberg does a great job of building up the tension for each assassination attempt the Israeli team tries on the members of Black September. Each time it seems that something goes wrong so it leaves the audience guessing what will happen next. Munich moves like a thriller but also is a morality tale on violence and revenge. Every member of the team heavily risks their own lives to complete their mission. The greatest example of the toll the mission takes on the men is Eric Bana's character. He has to leave his wife and newborn daughter, almost gets killed by his fellow team member, and begins to question whether the people they are after are really tied to Munich or not. By the end of the film, he becomes so paranoid that he hardly sleeps and is always watching his back.

Without a doubt Munich is Spielberg's most provocative film yet. Schindler's List was more of a tale about one man's change of heart and Saving Private Ryan asked the question of how much is one person's life worth. But Munich asks what is the price for killing someone. It seems to show that there is a heavy price and no reward. The men they kill are replaced by worse people and each of the members of the team become physically and emotionally destroyed in the process.

Munich is not Spielberg's best film, that belongs to Schindler's List. But in my opinion it could come an easy second with Saving Private Ryan. Bana gives his best performance yet and should at least be nominated for Best Actor, if not win it. Spielberg should get his third Best Director Oscar as he proves once again that he can tackle any subject no matter how controversial. Although I have not yet seen all of the movies that have gotten Oscar attention I think that Munich is the best film of 2005. If you have not seen Munich yet, I suggest that you do and get the rare experience of seeing a movie that not only thrills you but also makes you think.

Title: Terrorists Sleep lightly
Review:
I very much liked the film, although having read the book Vengeance in my late teens, I found the book better. To give a little background, I am 29 and I was in the Israeli army not so very long ago. While I did NOT commit any targeted killings or assassinations, I do not sleep as easily as I did in my youth, as there are many late nights. But regrets? - I did what I was called to do in defense of my country, and now I am proud to be able to be here in the greatest country in the world. I must admit it troubles me that many in America do not honor their sons and daughters who serve in military. Anyone who has not walked point or left on an action not certain if they would see first light, has no business saying anything. Hazak to Mr. Spielberg for a film that is relatively even in its approach. I sleep a little better knowing right now that somewhere a terrorist is sleeping with his gun, bug out bag at the ready, knowing there are hunters searching day and night.

Title: Poor at every level
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Emotionally realized, yet confusing
Review:
The film is full of emotion and interesting reflections upon real-life events. Having said this, it has its flaws. Though the film is very well realized both visually and in terms of narrative, some of the characters seem to have more significance than they actually do within the plot. For example, the old woman who seems to be the leader of the Israilies is a very undeveloped and difficult to understand character. The film can be compared to several of my personal favorites, including "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind" (George Clooney), "Catch me if you can" (Stephen Spielberg) and "Schindler's List" (Stephen Spielberg). Its is an amalgamation of the above, featuring the usual "Spielberg" combination of seriousness and humor. In conclusion, I thoroughly enjoyed the film and stayed "glued" to the screen for the whole 3 hours. However, I will go to see in again to try to understand the main character's involvement in the Munich Murders and the significance of the old woman mentioned above.

Title: Munich
Review:
Munich staring Eric Bana Wow! Went to see this film without knowing too much history about the 1972 Olympic hostage taking. I was not even born yet. I learned so much about Israel and walked out of the film with a greater knowledge of what the Israelites have gone through and the plight if there forefathers. I would highly recommend this film to all who have the slightest bit of interest in History and Israel. I now have decided to take a trip to Israel and check out the Kibbutz, and learn more of their history. The only problem I had with this film was the length, I think it could've had about twenty minutes shaved off, nearing the end I found myself looking at my watch wondering if it was ever going to end. Although I understood the need for it to be the length it was. If you can't sit still in a theater, wait for it to come to video. But do see this film and go in with an open mind. I applaud all the actors for a job well done and hope that this film gives people the message that was intended. Enjoy the movie!

Title: Excellent, but Craig a bit wooden.
Review:
Munich is a violent, gripping and provocative account of the aftermath of the 1972 Olympic Massacre. It is much less flag-wavingly patriotic than I expected and offers a well rounded view of the issues involved. I wouldn't have minded a little more insight into the civilian casualties of the vengeful attacks. The acting is quite superb for the most part, although the part of the bomb-maker is a touch stereotyped which makes him a little hard to believe. My only other moan is that one is left guessing a little at the end as to the outcomes of some of the characters involved. Craig will be great as James Bond! Overall I would thoroughly recommend this movie but would suggest that it is watched after 5 Days in September, the excellent documentary on the same topic.

Title: masterpiece? puhlease!
Review:
What a stinker. After reading about Spielberg's displeasure with regards to his studios apparent favoritism of Brokeback Mountain over Munich I felt compelled to give it a go and what a mistake. Anyone looking to catch up on their sleep will be pleasantly surprised. This thing sucked. Political ideologies aside, it was just plain boring. The fact that Israel sanctioned the assassination of the Munich terrorists would itself seem to foster an interesting enough screenplay but Spielberg manages to take any excitement and/or intrigue and bog it down with tiresome dialogue, bad accents and contrived characters. I found myself looking at my watch repeatedly wishing this steamer would end. Spielberg, check your ego at the door next time and leave the directing to someone with a pulse.

Title: Good but different movie
Review:
This movie will get your internal organs moving... lots of gory and very realistic scenes (not like Kill Bill that seemed like hot sauce); so watch who you bring to the theater and how their diet has been. It is based on real happenings, so that makes it very interesting to see all perspectives on how the middle east battles their internal differences, and takes justice on their hands. Be ready to bring a pillow or a electric massager for the chair, and don't drink too much pop; 'cause its a looong movie (2.5 hours; I didn't want to miss any part off it, but had to make a trip to the J :-(. Hope you like this interesting movie.

Title: Déjà vu
Review:
I just saw the movie. BUT I have the feeling that every scene that I was watching I have seen it before, years ago. Avner's recruitment, few of the killings, the girl at the bar, her elimination, Brooklyn. Was there another movie with similar scenery? I remember one with Michael York. Very odd. In the helicopter scene, historically, wasn't there a grenade thrown inside? I remember when this massacre happened, It was a completely useless act for the Palestinians, it did much more harm to their credibility, than good. My heart goes to both sides, hoping that one day they will throw down their arms and start using their mouth. Great movie though. Vicotor

Title: Movie tells both sides of story
Review:
This is an excellent movies that tells both sides of the story and is fair to all political factions involved. It is a mesmerizing movie, and thought provoking. It is far better the the drivel that has been coming out of Hollywood these days. Everyone with a social conscience and an interest in world peace should see this movie. Spielberg does not romanticize the events that have taken place or may have taken place. He gives us a hard look and a terrible period of our world's history. People may criticize the movie, but fair comment must come after viewing the movie and not reacting to hearsay and critics who have given the movie unfavorable press.

Title: Very intriguing film
Review:
Spielberg has once again directed a film that not only entertains you but keeps you thinking long after the credits roll. Munich manages to tell a true story with just enough embellishment to keep it entertaining while sometimes blurring the documentary line. Sometimes in the film he reminds us we are still in the narrative realm by being somewhat melodramatic. The violence is there too making it look creepily real. The idea of squads of assassins roaming the streets waging a secret war on each other leaving civilians in their wake is scary to say the least. The film had me captured from the beginning until the end and congratulations to Spielberg for directing yet another great film that will probably stand the test of time.

Title: still crying
Review:
This film destroyed me. Was not expecting that! I don't look to Spielberg for any kind of balanced argument. I was wrong! This film challenged me. It made me angry. It made me proud. I was never sure which was I was going with this whole thing ... good guys, bad guys. I was really affected by Daniel Craig, although Bana was great. I loved the little Truffaut-like Frenchman ... and the visit with his family. I guess I just expected to be dictated to and manipulated. Instead, I was opened up and twisted about. This is what I need from a movie. SEE IT! By the way, they make the minimum line requirement for submitting comments way too long. Way. Too. Long.

Title: Munich sucks
Review:
Take a true tragedy and make a (bad) thriller inspired by it? Sick idea. And for me that makes any kind of argument of its political content impossible.

So I am not into it. The film is a bunch of clichés connected loosely, and it is so boring I wanted to cut my own throat 30 minutes into it. The friend I went with did not let me leave the theater saying it is my punishment for taking him along to such a pathetic way of spending an entire morning.

And sorry girls, watching Eric Bana's beautifully sculpted butt for almost three hours just doesn't make up to it.

It was the movie I wanted to see most in the last few month - I am angry and disappointed. Mr.Spielberg managed to under-perform even A.I. Time to retire or make E.T.2.

Title: Lovely
Review:
I've watched the movie and i found it very interesting.I like films based on true stories, all i could say about the film is superlatives.Except one little thing : When Avner goes to Rome to kill the firs enemy, when hi killed him to the elevator the victim falls on his face.Aftre that Avner and his friend goes away.Few seconds after that there comes the cleaner, who takes the fired cartridge.I saw that the victim was on his back.That is little bug :).But the film is really charming.This is a fascinating story with a different viewpoints.I makes you think about the unsolvable problems between Jewish and Arabian people and makes you terrified from all the violence.

Title: Take the time to watch
Review:
Being born in 1972 is the only thing I have to relate to of this movie. But reading about this in my high school years gave me a very great interest to see this film when it was released. I have to say this was one of the most moving films I've watched in the last few recent years due to the feel of the era itself. The intensity will grip you from minute to minute and will make you think more of this world today. The authenticity of the characters roles were outstanding, along with the reality of these type of incidents some still might ignore. From the beginning it's a roller coaster with intense moments that pull you to the edge of your seat. Even if you have had no interest in this film because of the tragic circumstances you should watch this film as a reminder of what can happen again and again to humanity when loyalty and bloodshed can't distinguish right from wrong.

Title: A movie that should be seen
Review:
This movie should be seen by all those who are of the proper age and not of the faint of heart. It was thought-provoking and horrifying, but did a very good job of addressing the question of, is an eye for an eye really the answer. I am a teacher and will suggest that my older students go nd see the film, so that we can discuss the moral issues brought up in it and also, what else could have been done by the Israelis, after the Munich bombings, instead of what was done, if anything. The film was very violent, however, I believe the violent scenes were done in an appropriate way, if there is such a thing, so that it was more painful than absolutely, gut-wrenchingly gory--don't get me wrong, there are some of those scenes too, but the focus was more on the plot than the blood and guts. I believe this is an important movie about an incident that far too many people know far too little about. This is the best movie I have seen in years.

Title: Nine of the Eleven
Review:
Did anyone else notice at the end that 9 of the 11 targets were assassinated, and that they chose to print this info over the twin towers??? Coincidence?? I wasn't around yet when the attacks at Munich took place, but there are an awful lot of 9's and 11's when it comes to, well to be PC about it, this type of story.If there are any of you that may have more insight, I'd love to hear it. Overall, I found the film to be fabulous! It's the type of thing that I wish I had learned in school. The only time I heard of this was when my parents or grandparents talked about it. And that was usually a french-Canadian perspective.

Title: Israelis, STOP exploiting girls from the former Eastern bloc
Review:
In the Jan 11, 98 edition New Orleans Times-Picayune, Michael Specter wrote an article entitled "Slave-traders Lure Slavic Women" discussing how Israelis exploit girls from the former Eastern bloc:

"She was 21, self-assured and glad to be out of Ukraine. Israel offered a new world, and for a week or two everything seemed possible. Then, one morning, she was driven to the brothel, where her boss burned her passport before her eyes. "I own you," she recalled his saying. "You are my property, and you will work until you earn your way out. Don't try to leave. You have no papers and you don't speak Hebrew. You will be arrested and deported. Then we will get you and bring you back."

"The Women who work there, like nearly all prostitutes in Israel, are Russian, their boss is not. 'Israelis love Russian girls,' said Israeli slave master Jacob Golan...'They are blonde and good looking and different from us.'"

In the April 1998 edition of Moment magazine which bills itself as the "Magazine of Jewish Culture and Opinion," there was an article entitled "Hookers in the Holy Land"

"A good percentage of the customers - or Johns, in the lingo - are ultra-orthodox Jews, pious men whose lives are guided by halachah (religious law), which tells them when they can or cannot have sex with their wives. So, on Thursday afternoons, (boys night out in Israel) bus loads of Orthodox JEws travel from Jerusalem, Haifa, and points beyond to Tel Aviv for a few precious moments of passion in a massage parlor, behind a sand dune, or a in an alleyway. Other customers are accountants, lawyers, policemen, and politicans. 'The entire spectrum of Israeli society is keeping the hookers in business.' Claims Detective Shachar, a cynical veteran on the Tel Aviv detail...'Tel Baruch is so very absurd and so very Israel.'"

"once the girls arrive in Israel, the crime bosses take over. The girls are usually taken to an 'auction house,' where the owners of the various 'massage parlors' can bid on the talent - each one offers a price, and the highest bidder gets the girl...The girls are virtual slaves."

"Throw the pigs out!" -Kaiser Whilhelm II

Title: Depressing
Review:
OK - this was meant to be a serious film, but this was possibly the most depressing movie I have ever seen. It makes Schindlers List seem lighthearted. Yes it was cinematically powerful etc. etc. but it was just too miserable. Parts of the movie were also confusing and I thought it would be more factual but it appeared to cross the line into Hollywood particularly with the murders, their graphic nature and overacted scenes! This was further enhanced by the gratuitous sex scene with his pregnant wife!I can say I neither laughed nor cried once during this movie. It was like watching a three hour Panorama!As Spielberg directed, I was expecting a lot more, and the film had a lot of great reviews. Definitely not for me.

Title: Very powerful film to reflect on today's politics & media
Review:
I would like to praise Steven Spilberg for bringing three things to the fore: a) Violence only breeds more violence; b) Jewish morals are incompatible with the needs of a State and politicians; c) Nothing disappears, but what goes comes.

The movie brings the humane inside the manipulation of politics. When the actors reflect on their Jewishness, they cannot fulfill their function.

The toy maker says in one of his lines that he is losing his soul. The revenge does not bring peace but more blood. Everybody is a loser. The French resistance is still alive since the Second World War, nothing really disappears. Violence will breed more violence ad infinitum....

I wish that this movie will bring a change in the myths created by ideologies and should allow people in the Middle East to find a modus vivendi that will suit everybody. Moreover, I wish that the sons of Abraham should reflect in their origins, forgive each other and profit from the blessings received at that time.

Thank you to Mr. Spilberg and his crew

Title: I have seen this movie before
Review:
Has anyone out there seen the movie Sword of Gideon (released in 1986) Seems like Steven just did a bit of a rewrite. Similar plot. I was about 10 minutes into the movie when I realized this was a remake. My mind was telling me I had seen this movie before. The killer-babe in the bar. The explosive guys dying by his own device. Sword of Gideon is based on the novel Vengeance. Steven Bauer is Avner and does a great job. Michael York, Rod Steiger are in the cast. It was directed by Michael Inderson, who also directed two Orca movies, Logan's Run (Michael York again), Shoes of the Fisherman and the Quiller Memorandum. Seems to me that this movie deserved more praise and should have been mentioned in all the Spielberg hype.

Title: Remakes
Review:
Steven Spielberg's remake of the 1986 Sword of Gideon is a fine production but as I watched it the storyline of the 1986 production was being replayed almost exactly. Spielberg shows little in the way of originality in his film. Too bad he didn't acknowledge the 20 year old film as a source. Sword of Gideon is a better title for the piece. The cast was a good one in this latest production of the story of the assassins who hunted down those responsible for the killing of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. Although it is clear what happened at Munich it was not particularly clear exactly how all the athletes were killed nor how many of the killers were killed during the hostage taking. For dramatic effect, I suppose, Spielberg has chosen to present much of this as flashback in the form of nightmares of the Israeli assassin group leader. Detailing of this part of the story up front would have helped the storyline.

Title: Stock characters; stock scenes
Review: The movie is not really about Jews and Palestinians, except ostensibly. Anyone who sees it will become aware of how generic the whole thing is: just hunter vs. the hunted. The film is composed of repeated and not so inspired scenes that set up and show violence, each scene a little different, each scene a little tense, but each scene 'no name brand' action all the way. Stock characters, stock scenes. No villains. Who's a villain, the fat diplomat-guy sitting at his desk whose daughter plays the piano? Maybe he is, but from the movie's perspective we don't even know him. Not enough depth. No heroes: even Avner is not really well drawn. We got platitudes from his mother, and faithfulness from his wife. You don't ever see Palestinian counter-planning. And to think, Spielberg has been accused for being even-handed, or making the Israeli-Arab conflict into something smacking of moral equivalence. Not true. Had you seen Palestinian strategy at work you might have had a case to make for moral equivilance. But this flick was derivative of lots of other movies. "Capone" showed the possibility of a little girl getting blown-up in a bomb in a more dramatic way than did this movie. We got a touch of Hitchcock, a touch of the Le Carre spy who grows weary of the game. On and on. And it was all too long. And that shot of the Twin Towers? (They're coming here, too!) Scorsese did that in 'Gangs of New York.'

Title: Interesting film, but not original
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Shocking -- again
Review: After seeing the filming of Munich, the entire story came back to me. The movie is well done, but much too long and dragged out. For some obvious reason, the anger I felt in 1972, during and after this monstrous event. What anger? Of course the terrorists, who managed to get into the Olympic compound, and carry out their dirty job. The Germans, who did nothing and just let things happen, as they did. The Olympic committee, for continuing the games, as if nothing had happened, and the uncalled for reactions of the people responsible for this lack of caring. Stevem Spielberg, for managing to put a human face on the terrorists. His excuses at the beginning of the film, were uncalled for. Those terrorists, as well as the terrorists today, are inhuman monsters. When I heard the mention of releasing 200 of their prisoners, I saw no change today, where they kidnap, kill and request releasing terrorists, which we already did and they went back to their old terrorism. At the time of the these happenings, my neighbor in Michigan, who was at the Olympic Games, took the first flight home. She was sick and disgusted. She was not Jewish, but saw the inhumanity of the terrorists and the arrogance of the Germans. Angry? Yes! The movie is excellent, but it hits home and shows the terrorism, which has lasted to this day. By the way, my late husband, was one of the people sent a letter bomb when he was on diplomatic service for the UN, in the 1970's.

Title: Such a fantastic if hard to watch at times.
Review:
To start with Steve Spielberg is one if not the best in the business...every film albeit a couple of shockers (ready player one and AI being two very forgettable films) Munich however is what Spielberg does best, a story teller which sadly was based on true events. The cast was perfect, Eric Bana played his character so well, Daniel Craig again couldn't fault him, cirain hindes and the rest played this film out brilliantly.

Comments on here suggest factually the film was inaccurate but I for one really enjoyed the film, again as I commented earlier tragic and hard to watch at times but Spielberg does this so well... excellent film.

Title: definitely worth seeing
Review:
This was certainly one of the best movies that I have ever seen, I enjoyed the more 'realistic' and personal view of the Israeli retaliation against the Palistinians' terror attack on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich. Also, the tension in the movie only builds as the end nears, outlining the dilemma that a person in any comparable or metaphorical situation must face when making such a decision. The dilemma is whether or not 'action' will solve anything, will make the situation better off than beforehand and in retrospect, be worth it in light of what might happen as a result. Anyhow, I think that it is unfortunate that King Kong has grossed twenty times more than Munich so far, Kong was good, but Munich was definitely better. So any of you who have not seen it yet need to get on it.

Title: Great Movie+ As if Spielberg can do anything else
Review:
MUNICH is an excellent movie and deserves every award given. Having said that it could stand to be a little shorter. At 2 hours and 44 minutes one starts to notice the time past by the numbness in the butt. The story is the aftermath of the 1972 Munich Olympic Games terrorist attack. 11 Isreali hostages were taken and killed. The story revolved around what the Mossad (Isreali version of the CIA) did to those who funded and planned the attack. Eric Bana is surprisingly good in the role. He shows the guilt of an assassin as well as the determination of person doing what he believes is the right and true thing to do. Ciran Hinds is equally good and deserves award nominations as the cleaner This film is action packed and very thrilling. It does not shy away from blood and gore. Bombs are detonated and you see the true aftermath. People are shot and don't just grab where they were supposedly shot and fall over. You see the blood. Definitely earned the rating of R. Spielberg cares for the material and is shown in every minute of the movie

Title: Too Detail/Not Too Detail
Review:
First of all, I remember seeing this movie before. Almost 20 years ago I saw "SWORD OF GIDEON" starring Steven Bauer (Scarface) and Michael York. Both movies are based on the same book, but there are significant differences. The movie was a little long, some parts were too detail while others skipped passed details you may have found useful. The problem most likely is that only so much of the actual events are known. There are some mysteries that remain to this day I suppose. The movie gets a bit into the ideologies to most likely humanize the Mossad and the Terrorists. I think that since we are bombarded with the events of the middle east every day it wasn't important to include the discourse. There is something insinuated almost at the very end of the movie that I was surprised by...truth or theory I couldn't say.

Title: Great Film
Review:
i saw this movie last week with my best friend. each week (friday mostly) we go to see a movie. last week it was Munich. and i have to say that this has been one of the best movies i have seen in a long time. it had a bit of everything. I'm the kind of movie buff who likes all types of movies and i judge them all differently. i was sketchy about seeing this because one of my friends told me it was a waste of 3hours. but hes the type of guy who likes mindless meaningless movies. so i decided to go and see it. first off. it wasn't at my local movies. so then i drove 30mins to see it. when i got there i found out the showing (7:30pm) was sold out. so i then decided to wait till the 11:30pm Showing. and after the movie was out. it was worth the drive and wait. i would recommend this movie to pretty much anyone. its worth the 2hours and 45mins. and worth a drive and wait if u have to. i give this film a 9/10 if not a full 10/10.

ps: sorry about my spelling and grammar. I'm on a school computer typing this.

Title: Don't waste your time
Review:
I can't get over the terrific reviews this movie got and all the positive comments in this site. I found this movie to be ponderous. Way too long. Way too heavy. Way too repetitive. Way too boring. It's depressing, dark, hopeless, and pointless.

Watching Bana struggle with his angst for over 2 hours was almost more than I could take. I hung in there to the end, though, hoping for a satisfying ending. Instead I got a ridiculous sex scene where our "hero" is envisioning gruesome murders while in the act. Sure, I know it was symbolic of something or other, but by the time we got to it, I was too bored to care.

Also, our "hero" is a glamorized murderer. He knows it, even if Goeffrey Rush does his best to justify it in the name of national security. Sound familiar?

Then we have the cinematography that everyone is raving about. I found the washed out, grainy texture, and artsy lighting totally at odds with the realistically gruesome death scenes that littered this movie. After you've seen the first few heads blow apart, and smoke rising from the bullet riddled bodies, it gets a bit old. It wasn't as drawn out as in Saving Private Ryan, but you can tell he used the same special effects people.

I guess I'm just not hip or cool enough to really appreciate this movie, but I wonder how many of the people who are gushing over it would do so if the director's name wasn't Spielberg. Spielberg has been taking himself way too seriously ever since he had such success with Schindler's list. That was a masterpiece, and I have the feeling he keeps trying to equal it or better it with his subsequent films. It just ain't happening.

One final note. There was a much better take on these events in the 1986 movie "Sword of Gideon". It was based on the same book with the same characters and story, but without the preaching.

Title: Not Worthy of Spielberg...Boo
Review:
I'll give this a 5 out of ten and I'll tell you why. As great a filmmaker as Spielberg is, and I count one of his movies in my Top Ten, this is not worthy. He is basically making a remake or a slight altered version of a the film that has been made. This film based on the same novel by George Jonas is called "Sword of Gideon" and was made in 1986. Partially in Canada I might add. However, regarding the authenticity and budget of this film ("Sword of Gideon"), it shows a vision that is far superior due to the restraints of the production, cast and crew team. I respect what Spielberg has done in the past, but I would like to see what he could make on a shoestring budget in the present day. "Sword of Gideon" is a far superior film.

A note to our friend, Michael from the States. "Saving Private Ryan" was another miss by Spielberg. The first 15 minutes were totally interesting, then it got boring. How can you disrespect the works of other great directors you've mentioned??? Stone, Coppola and Minghella. I suggest you familiarize yourself more on film before you criticize it. Read some of the interesting posts on the "Sword of Gideon" page!! It just goes to show you sometimes Money Talks!!.....NuffSaid.........

Title: some flaws
Review:
here are some of the flaws that I saw. 1)Unlike Schindler's List, it didn't draw in the viewer. The acting was excellent but Avner remained emotionally unattached to the AUDIENCE. He was not someone that we (or I) could identify with. 2)the subplots weren't developed. Who were the different people? Why were the Israelis chasing them (besides being terrorists)? The role of some of the terrorists was unclear. 3)In conjuction to #2, there were too many (yes, I know that it was a global net work)who just were mentioned or appeared and just as quickly disappeared without much explanation...including the Israelis 4)The safe house scene was confusing 5)Was anyone also confused about the roles of Papa and his son? (yes, they were selling info, but why and why did Papa remain aloof from son? The garden scene with Avner: what was that about? 6)Avner's mom/ima? Why was she even IN the film? 7)it was about 45 minutes too long, it dragged in parts.

All that to say, a little on the boring side. The real event affected me profoundly.

Title: Great Piece of History!
Review:
Steven Spielberg has just scored another triumph following War of the Worlds which was a huge box office smash! Eric Bana is so lucky to work with Steven along with many of the other actors including the always talented Gefforey Rush who was remarkable as the case officer. A true piece of world history brought to life by one of the most influencle filmmakers of all time! It is brilliantly shot with good use of archival footage of the real Munich event. The cast was so into the world around them as if they were actually experiancing it for themselves. The score was chilling. John Williams made a good use of a singer making the score more effective than some of his other works. The film was a fantastic piece of history brought to life!

Title: Not bad, but lets face it, sloppy film-making
Review:
So who were these French guys and why are they connected to everyone? How did Avner's high school buddy's girlfriend happen to know them? Why was no one angry with the Frenchies after the safe house fiasco? Why was Salaami's house so poorly guarded and why would Avner and Daniel Craig be able to get that close and have a clear shot, and then be able to run away from gunfire. This film, while trying to make a statement, simply required too many leaps of faith for me to really take it seriously. Several times I was thinking that it seemed fake. Sorry Mr. Spielberg, you can't expect people to overlook these "trivial" matters, regardless of the films message.

Title: One by One
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: A must watch
Review:
Everyone on the film pulled their weight and it shines through in every aspect of the movie.

Title: Spielberg's greatest work
Review:
This movie was a delightful surprise for me. It is my tentative vote for best picture of the year. It has all the elements of a great movie. There is a good amount of violence, a good amount of nudity, great dialog, great acting, great directing, interesting plot. The length was a little less than three hours, and I was never bored. Although at some moments this movie was visually disturbing (graphic violence) I walked out of the movie with a great taste in my mouth. Eric Banna captures the fear of being hunted by unknown enemies perfectly, and all of the rest of the roles are cast perfectly. Much of the movie was shot in Europe, and these scenes are beautiful and do a good job of capturing European daily life. I can't think of another time when I was more pleased by a Spielberg film.
