Title: Not disappointed
Review: I've seen this movie 3 days ago, with a friend. I'm neither a Muslim nor a Jew. I went to see the movie because it was the only one i hadn't seen yet, i wasn't especially looking forward to it, neither was my friend, but we were at the cinema, and it was freezing cold outside. So at first, knowing Spielberg 's a Jew, i was a little afraid the movie might be pro- Israel, not really showing both sides of the conflict. U know, mean Arabs, poor nice Jews, that kind of thing. But happily, i realized -but once again i want to repeat i'm not especially involved in the conflict and i surely don't know much about it, except from what i read in the newspapers which i don't think is reliable- that Spielberg, didn't only show Jews as victims and Arabs as terrorists. To me, the meaning of the movie, is that in both sides there are terrorists and victims at the same time. When i see the reaction of people in this very website, i simply cannot understand how religion which is supposed to be all about love and respect can still lead to so much hate, and i mean, it's just a movie. Another message of the movie i agree with, through all the many wars mankind has lived, why haven't we learned the lesson yet : killing human beens shall never be a solution to any problem at all. I know i'm not saying anything new or really clever. I'm just a young woman, living in a world i mainly know by what some books or papers say about, i don't live in the place where the fight is going on, but from my point of view, which is certainly very naive and simple, it seems no god who requires children, men or women to be killed in his name deserves anyone to believe in him anyway.

Title: Munich: long but good
Review:
Munich is about the actions taken after the murder of 11 Israeli athletes in the 1972 Munich Olympics. After watching it I have to say that it has earned itself a place in my favorite spy movies. The plot moves along fast enough to keep you interested and at the same time they still make progress with how much time they spend on a certain aspect. two thumbs way up for the filming done, not just because of the good portrayal of the true brutality of the nature of murder, but also when elements of the storyline are mixed together. Another element that adds to the movie is the fact that it is based on actual events further adding to the surrealism.

Title: Is this popular
Review:
I've just seen this movie today, as it was only released in Australia on Thursday (Jan 26, Australia Day). Despite it being a bit too long, I really thought it was very good, better than I expected.

What I would like to know, is this movie popular in the US? I'm confused because it has only appeared on the US Box Office Top 10 three times and has since dropped off. Was it well received there, is it popular? Just curious.

I'm sure it did veer from the facts, as all movies do, but I thought it was very interesting. (N.B. I do not know enough about the situation to comment or take sides, so please reserve those opinions for another thread).

Title: Good Action/Suspense, Intriguing Story, Unsatisfying Finish
Review:
Munich is a great action/suspense movie, which unlike many films of its genre also has a very intriguing storyline and conflict. The problem was the movie's resolution. Munich does indeed ask very tough (and good) ethical questions, but provides answers that are WAY too easy. In case anyone is wondering, the story is not actually about the 1972 Olympic Incident-thats just the backdrop. Rather, the movie is about revenge in general, and whether violence justifies more violence. Without providing any specific plot details, my main problem with the "easy" answers is that Spielberg presents a whole complicated world with many shades of gray, then takes a black and white stance supporting one side at the end. Note: NOT for the faint of heart (there are some VERY gruesome death images).

Title: Spielberg deals with reality once again to good effect
Review:
I have to confess to not knowing as much as I think I ought to about the continuing problems in Israel. The events of Munich 1972 were previously unknown to me other than the basic premise that there was a terrorist attack. For someone who may not grasp why even today Palestine and Israel are at each other's throats Munich provides some of the ideals at the core of the problem. The film, as with Schindler's List, doesn't hold back from showing you the realities of events that have happened, which perhaps adds to its impact.

The film as a form of entertainment may not hold the attention of some but instead is more of a case study into terrorism and counter terrorism. Eric Bana provides a really good performance as the central character helping form a human connection to the story. It is also not a specific side driven piece even if it is told from one point of view it doesn't sugar-coat everything. The reality is quite shocking and Spielberg's direction as usual is excellent, it is also helped by a good script that only begins to lose its pace by the end of what is quite a long film.

I would recommend people seeing this in order that, as with the holocaust in Schindler's List, it becomes more than just history, even with fictional characters and events mixed into the actual events. This makes it more real and increases your understanding and perception of what could otherwise just be events happening a while ago in far off places. The atmosphere is tense and is heightened by the music of the ever reliable genius that is John Williams. Along with Bana there are also good supporting roles for Geoffrey Rush and Ciaran Hinds who added two very interesting characters.

Munich may have caused controversy but you have to really try to fault Spielberg as a film maker. Whether its dinosaurs, terrorists or alien invasions he somehow finds an extra level that most other directors don't reach.

Title: Watch it on DVD not in a cinema it is just not worth it.
Review:
The cast is great, by the way. But the film just took to long and dragged some scenes to the point that I thought I am going to just walk out of the cinema. Spielberg could have made a great film and the story was good but it just wasn't what I expected from it. The hostage of the athletes had only a minor role in this film. Well the main characters some kind of flashbacks of the hostage situation but how can he know about those details while he just wasn't there. I thought the cast was great especially the main character and Daniel Craig was good to but it just wasn't worth the money and I recommend to watch it on DVD when it is released.

My regards, JuX

Title: Look at comment
Review:
WOW..This movie was so much more than what I was expecting. The movie shows the angst of each of the main characters as they question whether their loyalty to their country and religion is worth killing men with loving families. Though I will not discuss what I believe to be the film's underlying theme, their are poignant scenes which underscore the futility of violence. While I do not know Spielberg's politics, anyone who says this movie takes sides is simply wrong. Like "Requiem for a Dream", this is a movie I believe many people with experience in the subject ought to see. In my opinion, this movie is the year's Best Picture so far.

Title: Excellently directed and performed but lacking in direction
Review:
As the synopsis says, the movie focuses on Avner and his team of untrained assassins trying to take out the Palestinians involved in the 1972 slaying of Israeli Olympians. Steven Spielberg, as expected, did an excellent job directing the movie and both the performances of the ensemble together and Eric Bana individually were outstanding. The movie brings up thought-provoking ideas about terrorism and vengeance, however, it is not until the last twenty minutes of the movie that they are explored. Most of the movie is spent following the team through its attempts to assassinate the members of Black September. Although there are brief images and references to the themes explored later in the movie, I felt that the movie was more thriller/drama than the drama/thriller as which it has been billed. This is not to say that the movie missed the point, but it was not until late in the movie that the viewer was shown the moral consequences faced by the characters and the ramifications of their actions.

I feel that this is the only problem with the movie however. As stated above, the movie is excellently made and well presented, but I feel that the screenplay was lacking in substance, which takes away from the excellence of the other aspects of the film. The movie is very good and is definitely worth seeing, but was ultimately a disappointment, considering who worked on it.

Title: Munich - didn't like it
Review:
I just left Spielberg's Munich, and found it to be a waste of time. It was too long, too predictable and quite boring. Plots and subplots were just so much rehash of many other stories and styles. Very disappointing.

This certainly was not Spielberg's best work.

Acting was minimally acceptable, too many scenes were contrived and kept me from being swept into the film's characters and plots, which I deem the sign of a good work.

Despite the subject matter, I found a significant lack of political and social intensity. Perhaps my expectations were too high.

At least I got to see some beautiful European street scenes and architecture. For that I gave a score of 3/10. But this alone can't make up for a long and tedious time spent in an uncomfortable seat.

Title: Excellent review on Munich
Review:
Read this wonderful review on Munich.

http://www.idlebrain.com/research/ramblings/ramblings-munich.html.

It is impossible to ignore the burden of history involving Israel and Palestine, in any act that involves these two constantly warring sides, with one fighting for a right to survive and the other fighting for a right to exist in the same few thousand square miles, which is ironically considered to be the most sacred of lands to all the major religions involved - Islam, Judaism and Christianity. With the world polarized about the issue of taking stands of one against the other, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict almost took the shape of a morality issue, where one man's freedom fighter became another man's terrorist.

Read the entire review at the link provided.

Thanks to Sri Srinivas Kanchibhotla. Excuse me for posting it here.

Title: Long, confused, boring but well acted
Review:
I found this film unnecessarily long (2 3/4 hours)which made me wish that I could have edited it. I could have cut at least an hour out without damaging it in any way. The flashbacks were choppy and in some cases unintelligible. More time should have been given to the actual massacre up front and the flashbacks would have been unnecessary. The picture felt very propagandistic to me and I can see why Spielberg was accused of being anti-Israel.

I will say however that the acting was excellent and the use of lesser known actors was effective. Somehow, I could not have seen Tom Cruise taking the part of Avner. I would give this film 2 stars at best.

Title: A Great Movie
Review:
Munich is a great movie, definitely one of Spielberg's best films. Munich shouldn't be looked upon as just as a drama, thriller, or action film, but a piece of history that everyone should know about. Spielberg tells the story in a violent, brutal and mature fashion. More importantly, he makes the film feel more real than any other film inspired by true events. The events that take place after the murders of the athletes in the film are intriguing. You will be tuned in, and at the same time feel uneasy. This is much on the same level as Saving Private Ryan and Schindler's List, but this time around the main characters aren't portrayed as heros or monsters, just men on mission in which they aren't entirely prepared for emotionally. The performances are great, especially Eric Bana who i hope gets recognition this time around.

While the mood and tone of the film is perfect, the films editing has a few problems. Some scenes could have gone/been shortened. The sex scene intercut with the Munich killings bothered me the most. Even if the intercutting had its own message, i still feel Munich killings shouldn't have been intercut at all. The editing also creates some confusion and it is at times hard to follow whats going, sometimes feeling like you've been left out some important points. You'll have your gripes, but certainly not as much as you did with War of the Worlds :) Its not perfect, and some of Spielbergs decisions may be controversial, but its still an important film and its problem hurt the experience little. Highly recommended.

Title: Uninspiring
Review: I have seen better and expected better work from Spielberg. Munich offers several great performances, like those of Eric Bana and Geoffery Rush. However, while the story is influenced by the actual events that follow the Munich massacre, it offers very little to movie goers who are looking to be entertained. Munich drags along while making generic and exhausted points on Middle Eastern politics that anyone who is even remotely familiar with the Arab-Israeli conflict would already be tired of seeing. If you're looking for an engaging political thriller, go see Syriana. If you're interested in the Arab-Israeli conflict, I would recommend that you borrow a book from your local library, and not watch Munich. The only thing that saves this movie from a lower rating, in my opinion, is Eric Bana's performance, which is certainly Oscar worthy. The only good part of the movie was the 15 second conversation between the bomb maker and Avner in the airport, before Avner and the other men leave to find the Dutch assassin. Finally, the movie ends without resolution, much like the nature of the Arab-Israeli conflict. This story would make a good documentary, but not a good feature film. If you're annoyed by the ongoing Arab-Israeli conflict, you will be annoyed by this movie also.

Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Average
Review:
I took 6 18- 20 year old to see this and to them it was awful, i have to agree compared to his other work this Spielberg film was poor. The plot is good as are the actors, but the most important thing is it takes too long to tell the story. The build up to each action scene diverted into irrelevant areas. There are two sex scenes that are just not relevant. The shock horror moments are shocking because the volume in the cinema is too loud and the gore is too visible, he needs to go back to Jaws to remember about suspense. I would also question why they put subtitles in for some dialogue and not others. This film could loose at least 30 mins and it would perhaps flow a little better. I have tried not to give the plot away so that people can judge themselves.

Title: simply heist
Review:
i never really understood what happened at Munich. Simply because i just didn't read into it, but after watching this movie,i was captivated. I'm not saying either that this movie is perfect. No one was actually there. But the people that were are dead,and of course there simply too many sides to this tragic event to actually have 1 extraordinary movie.I saw it as just the both sides without being biased about it.What they did as vengeance .Eric Bana ,must say this film is his finest yet. I love movies that keep me anxious.This was Exactly it! I felt connected to these characters. i felt i was part of the Entente. The most captivating part that sensed like "the fall of superman" was towards the end when he really became "the man who slept in his Closet". After that scene i was completely in love/already lust with Avner. He definitely has that intenseness about him.That makes him a real actor. According to me...

Title: Quality movie
Review:
In spite of what some people might say, we (my husband and I)love the movie. It gives a nice view on the stupidity on both sides. Spielberg doesn't take sides, but had to choose from which point of view to show what happened then and what is still going on at the moment. In Belgium a lot of Jews en Arabs live in the same neighborhoods and are trying to live peacefully together.

The movie had beautiful screen-shots, extraordinary music and the cast was well chosen. This is a high quality movie with great potential of letting people thing about certain things. I was surprised to see how well Spielberg captured certain situations and succeeded in keeping the viewer chained to their chairs. The movie is showing in Belgium from 25th January. We were two of the lucky ones to see it in premiere.

I would love to see more quality movies like this!

Title: Spielberg has made a mess by trying to criticize US indirectly
Review:
It's a shame this pro terrorist film uses the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians to actually criticize THE US and Bush without doing so directly, because Spielberg is too scared to lose over 50% of his US paying customers he sacrifices Israel instead, blurring the lines between terror and anti terror. He wants to say to president Bush what he really thinks of his policies and actions after 9/11.

Why do I say this? In the book "vengeance" Avner comes back to Israel and goes back to being an officer in the army ( his pre mossad job ) and in Spielberg's film Avner stays in NY city, and the twin towers are seen in the background as if to confirm and make all the movies statements on violence true.

In the book "vengeance" the idea of anti terror is explained: to buy time, when a well established terrorist ring is whipped out it takes years to reorganize and lives of civilians are saved.

Another thing that didn't ring true is making "black September" terrorist "freedom fighters" they never represented Palestinians and should not be confused as fighting for the Palestinian people, black September kidnapped the athletes in order to get 200 More terrorists out of Israeli prisons.

Spielberg has made a mess by trying to criticize US indirectly; as a result he offends many sides

Title: The Best Film of 2005!
Review:
Gandhi said, "An eye for an eye only makes the whole world blind." What distinguishes justice from vengeance? This echoes throughout Steven Spielberg's "Munich". "Munich" is powerful and perhaps Spielberg's most compelling and thought provoking work. He weaves a tapestry of political and social threads focusing on terrorism and the cost of violence. "Munich" is truly amazing in balancing linear storytelling and horrific acts of violence, demonstrating the impact of the aftermath. Spielberg's "Munich" seen through the eyes of Eric Bana's Avner is a powerful allegory that even in the most just and noble fights against terror we eventually become that which we despise. "Munich" really serves as a reminder. Mossad team leader Avner played by Eric Bana is absolutely riveting as the man who begins this righteous cause only to find that the cost is his soul. Anver asks, "When does it ever end?"

At the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Palestinian terrorists brutally murdered the Israeli wrestling team. This political statement was seen around the world and depicted in gory detail by Director Spielberg. Based on the book "Vengeance" by George Jones, the screenplay by Tony Kushner and Eric Roth tells the story of the aftermath of this tragedy. A great Lynn Cohen who plays Prime Minister Golda Meir says, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." Poetic words for what follows are a search and destroy mission. The Mossad assembles a team lead by Avner (Bana) to track down and kill with extreme prejudice all those involved in the terrorist action in Munich. 11 names are identified for execution. These executions are also intended to serve as statements. Anver though an inexperienced operative and not an assassin is selected for the covert mission by Ephriam (the great Geoffrey Rush) for being a strong and effective leader of men. The assassin team is composed of Steve (Daniel Craigthe next James Bond), Carl (Ciaran Hinds), Robert (Mathieu Kassovitz), and Hans (Hanns Zischler). They are dissociated from the Mossad, i.e. they technically don't exist.

In accepting the lead, Avner must leave his beautiful and pregnant wife Daphna (a very strong Ayelet Zorer) for what could be a number of years. Carl has his doubts about Avner, telling him that he was chosen because he is a "good soldier". Soon Carl respects Avner for his quiet force and conscience. Attack of conscience and paranoia soon engulf the team as they become entrenched in the world of underground intelligence for hire. Avner pays large sums of money for information on the whereabouts of his targets from Louis (wonderfully shady Mathiew Amalric) and his wealthy Papa (weary and noble Michael Lonsdale). Avner soon finds that whomever he kills is eventually replaced, and that he and potentially his family is now a target for the terrorists he was assigned to hunt down and kill. The realization is that it truly never ends. Bana is amazing as a trapped animal in the scene in his thrashed apartmentsearching for weapons of his demise. Paranoia sets in, and the path of justice and vengeance become blurred. In a poignant scene Robert pleads to Avner, "When I lose my righteousness, I lose everything"

Nothing about "Munich" is easy, though it is simple. I believe that is Steven Spielberg's intention. "Munich" could be tighter in spots, though this does not diminish the movie's power and impact. Eric Bana emerges as the noble hero battling to salvage his own humanity and his very soul. "When does it ever end?" Perhaps even in the current context there is no real answermaybe what Spielberg is getting at. It is a reminder of our humanity, that even the most righteous cause may cost our souls. "Munich" is truly a powerful movie worth seeing.

Title: Hearted film
Review:
whereas any critics about the equalization of contra- and terrorism, this picture set a remarkable idea. the world won't be secure if the people ain't got a home. i think Bana's performance needs the Oscar. it's about violence, not so about murders, but about your life been used by the militaries that "protect you". and there is a brilliant point when Avner is thinking about his loyalty, where he belongs to? the french militia are even more trustsworthy than the army of his country. he belongs to his wife and daughter. about jews and arabs in the little country of palestina, about one by one and one by millions of deaths, the chaotic war beneath the news.

Title: the purpose of the film
Review:
For any movie,there is always a target that a director and screenwriter want to hit? what was it in this film? If it was to achieve suspense and action movie ,they did. If it was to convey that the aim justifies the means ,they also did.If it was to condemn violence ,they hardly succeeded.And if it was to look at the events of the struggle between Palestinians and Israelis with a neutral eye ,they failed. Despite the conversation between Ali and Avner which included hints on the homeless Palestinians , it was not enough to convince the audience of the fair case that the Palestinians fight for. What the film did was depicting the Israeli team as heroes and Palestinians as terrorists.Nevertheless,Ephraim's words :'kill for peace' raises the question: which kind of peace built on others'bodies can the Israelis achieve?

Title: Just seen the movie. It has re enforced my feelings that violence achieves nothing but more violence
Review:
I am a British nurse who has cared for civilian victims in Vietnam ('67-70) Cambodia (79-80),Lebanon(83-85)Saudi Arabia (88-93). After 16 years in the Middle East I have come to understand how people see things in Egypt, Lebanon, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates and Saudi.) Munich was a brave film for Spielberg to undertake, and he did not pull any punches. It highlights the futility and heart break of vengeance. It will take politicians of courage, vision and initiative to draw a line under this tit for tat violence. Where are the world leaders with this courage? We need you now as never before, and this film illustrates that clearly. The old way of thinking is just that - old.Outdated. If we are to move forward in this world, we have to ditch the old idea of an eye for an eye, a tooth for a tooth. There is still time.

Title: despite the film
Review: i have watched the film.i should say it is very clever way see events in Hollywood.i would not talk about Spielberg or Jewish way of making film.but i would like to know why is the source of "black September".why these "Arabs" are willing to kill Israeli's. the way of film is to make us to be absent for the killed assassins of Israel.but don't forget there is a sentence after Munich event that Israel's killed 200 civilians in palest.so assassination didn't begin with Munich.read about Israel history.if you read real history you would see this is a political act of Israel today truth is lost in middle east.because people are fighting for so many years.but shouldn't person like assassin leader(Eric Ban) think before killing people. if you have no change to say you are in bad condition you cant talk about ethic.so Arabs have no channel to say what they live in that region.i am not in the part of terrorists but, we should decide what the terrorism is. a nation cant be a terrorist.character that Eric Ban playing is terrorist or not.if it is who supported and educated him to do this.so if you want to (and willing to ask) questions , you will find real answers and fell lonely in my opinion after this film search for real events. if you don't this film takes you to the wrong place

Title: a serious look at the cycle of violence
Review:
An excellent but gruesome window into the world of terrorism, how it affects innocent lives and how retaliation just leads to more terrorism. Innocent lives of victims but also of loved ones of those involved, from all sides deeply affected by these acts. Eric Bana is brilliant as the lead character, starting off so confidently and then living in fear as the tables turn. Also, interesting how real assassins work and had to cope with lack of technology such as cellphones etc which we have today. Having to be so close to the targets to set off devices made it hit them harder emotionally whereas today, assassins can be really far away from their target and achieve "neater" cold-blooded results. Scenery of European cities is touchable and the reconstruction of various memoirs from the 70's is well done, such as the fashion, transport, technology etc. A must see, gripping, serious movie. Could have been a little shorter but excellent. (PS: to Daniel Craig (Steve) - South African Jews sound more English in accent than Australian! We look forward to seeing you as 007!)

Title: Yeah, a fun fiction film....
Review:
I saw the film in the cinema with my sister (she didn't know nothing about the Munich massacre and still doesn't, but that's OK), to be honest I enjoyed it... It was a nice Hollywoodian film. I mean, I can compare this film to 007, Mission Impossible, or Men in Black...A nice plot, very interesting but definitely unreal .It's a fiction movie.

In the beginning its written "Based on real facts", I can say that the only real fact was the Munich Massacre. It's not reasonable to believe that Mossad (one of the world's best-known and most highly regarded intelligence agencies) actually contract non-prepared people to their missions, their agents are known as the most prepared ones. The best proof of it it's in the Operation Wrath of God, which was accomplished professionally.

But Steven Spielberg's inspiration it's the worst thing: the book "Vengeance: the True Story of an Israeli Counter-Terrorist Team" known as being not accurate and exaggerated, not a really good source. But I had fun watching it, and that's the important!!!!I recommend it.

Title: A fictional movie..
Review:
I always liked movies by Steven Spielberg. He made me look in my car mirror for a killer-truck. He made me weep when E.T. was a pale crying puppy ...and don't get me started on the Indiana series. But, when it comes to a 'facts-based' movie like "Munich", he should have changed the title to "N.Y.", "Cairo", "Moscow", "Berlin" or any other irrelevant name. The most appropriate name would have been "Munich - My own interpretation".

This movie is not based on historical evidence. This is history re-written by Hollywood motivation. Looks like truth is not relevant in the 20th (21st) century.

Title: just what i think
Review: hello everyone. I tried to watch this film ignoring the fact that is based on a true event. Why?. Spielberg is confusing me very much. I don't know if he wants to make a movie to get more money or if he really wants to narrate a very important event. the formula of Spielberg worked really well in "SAVING PRIVATE RYAN" but since then with movies like "WAR OF THE WORLDS" you can notice that the formula can't work all the time. So he mixes drama-adventure-action to get all the audiences, get recognized and money. But try to look the movie as just a movie and you will see how the characters repeat themselves in previous movies and the plot is so simply that when you remember that is based on true events what you can think it's: "Human race is so stupid". Revenge that's the secret of the movie. And some people are proud about it. I do not support any kind of killing and surely i do not take side, i just fell sorry for the families of the people who died. the movie don't deserve any award i think, it's just another movie. Besides the people who lived that event must remember it really well and a movie like this, i think, can't make a deep change on the things that people believe. IT's too personal.

Title: The best film I have seen this year!
Review:
This film was absolutely outstanding! It had a terrific base for a plot, and the way this was put on to the screen was brilliant. It had amazing acting in it, and i thought that they handled a delicate issue well in making this film. I have to say i am thoroughly glad i went and watched it, it is the best film i have seen this year! It was intricately put together and although it seemed complex, you were able to follow it throughout and wouldn't get lost. I would recommend that anyone who is thinking about watching it should definitely watch it. Wooo, what a film! I am absolutely astounded, i am lost for words by how good it actually is. I am definitely buying it when it comes out on DVD.
